<P>operations between ORD, JFK, and IAD and Delhi.</P>
<B><P>C. </B>Pilots assigned to a DEL pairing shall receive a period free from duty at the </P>
<P>end of each trip pairing consisting of not less than two nights (2300 to 0700) rest </P>
<P>at their domicile before being assigned other flying.</P>
<B><P>D</B>. Operations between DEL and HKG are already permitted under the provisions </P>
<P>of Section 3-A above (Pacific Operations), which shall continue to apply to the </P>
<P>operation of the HKG-LHR and HKG-DEL segments.</P>
<B><P>E</B>. No pilot scheduled into DEL will be scheduled or reassigned to fly or </P>
<P>deadhead multiple segments in excess of eleven and one half (11 1/2) time </P>
<P>zones away from his home domicile, without his concurrence. (A TDY domicile is </P>
<P>considered the pilot's home domicile for the purposes of this paragraph).</P>
<B><P>F. </B>Trip pairings involving operations to DEL scheduled under the provisions of </P>
<P>Section 3-B above will be limited to a maximum of 4 duty periods unless the </P>
<P>pilot(s) involved agree to an exception.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>No pilot will be scheduled or required to fly or deadhead from or through DEL </P>
<P>in a direction away from his domicile, without his concurrence. (A TDY domicile is</P>
<P>considered the pilot's domicile for the purposes of this paragraph).</P>
<B><P>H. </B>B767 aircraft scheduled between LHR and DEL will provide a pilot rest seat</P>
<P>consisting of a single International First Class seat in the non-smoking section of </P>
<P>the First Class cabin.</P>
<B><P>I</B>. When a pilot is required to deadhead (either on or off line) to or from DEL, the</P>
<P>pilot will be seated in First Class or Business Class if First Class is not available. </P>
<P>In no case will the pilot be required to deadhead in Coach Class.&nbsp;&nbsp;The </P>
<P>Association will provide the Company with a list of acceptable airlines for the </P>
<P>scheduled deadheading of UAL pilots.</P>
<B><P>J. </B>The layover hotel in Delhi will be selected by the Association from the Hyatt</P>
<P>Regency or the Welcomgroup Maurya Sheraton.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company will not change </P>
<P>hotels as a result of a rate increase without providing the Association 60 days </P>
<P>notice prior to the change.&nbsp;&nbsp;The parties will begin the process of obtaining </P>
<P>another mutually acceptable hotel(s) to serve as an available backup, in the </P>
<P>event the current hotel becomes unavailable.&nbsp;&nbsp;A crew lounge will be provided by </P>
<P>the hotel for use by United crews. If technologically feasible, a Unimatic terminal </P>
<P>will be provided at the hotel within a reasonable period of time and made </P>
<P>available to United crews. </P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page111</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;J-1- </B>If a room at the scheduled layover hotel is not available within 15 </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;minutes of scheduled check-in time, the affected pilot may seek other </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;accommodations and claim reasonable actual lodgings expense on the regular </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Company expense account form supported by the hotel receipt as provided in </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Section 4-B-1-c-(1) of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;J-2- </B>In addition to the provisions of Section 2-B-5, transportation to and from </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the Hotel will be provided by full size air conditioned private vehicle </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(exclusively for crews) with normal safety equipment and qualified driver.&nbsp;&nbsp;The </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;size of the vehicle will be commensurate with the needs of an International </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;flight crew with luggage.</P>
<B><P>K. </B>The Company will explore the possibility of obtaining a corporate membership </P>
<P>at a travelers or expatriate club which specializes in English-speaking </P>
<P>membership in Delhi for the purpose of providing pilots on layover with </P>
<P>membership services.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company is committed to providing this service if </P>
<P>such services are available and can be acquired at a cost no greater than that </P>
<P>paid by other international airlines that provide their crews with such services in </P>
<P>Delhi.</P>
<B><P>L. </B>European or North American bottled drinking water meeting U.S. Health</P>
<P>Department standards for purity will be made available at the layover hotel to </P>
<P>layover crew members in India. Bottled water will also be made available to pilots </P>
<P>on flight segments operating to and from DEL.</P>
<B><P>M. </B>Aircraft used on flights to, from, or within India will have a priority lavatory lock</P>
<P>system (similar to the 747-400 system) installed within a reasonable period of </P>
<P>time.</P>
<B><P>N. </B>Agreement will be reached between UAL Flight Operations management and </P>
<P>the MEC Chairman on operational issues associated with India service, including</P>
<P>depressurization escape routes and aircraft routings.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION </B>8- GENERAL</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">A. </B>Reassignment under Section 20-F-2 and 20-I must return the pilot to his home</P>
<P>domicile for a legal rest within thirty-six (36) hours of his originally scheduled </P>
<P>arrival at his home domicile if reassigned while in the Atlantic operation and </P>
<P>within forty-eight (48) hours of his originally scheduled arrival at his home </P>
<P>domicile if reassigned while in the Pacific operation. If, however, the pilot's duties </P>
<P>in his reassignment commence within the last forty-eight (48) hours in an Atlantic </P>
<P>assignment or sixty (60) hours in a Pacific assignment prior to his originally </P>
<P>scheduled arrival at his domicile, the reassignment as given will not delay his </P>
<P>return to domicile for more than forty-eight (48) hours of his originally scheduled </P>
<B><P>Page 112</P>
</B><P>arrival at his home domicile if reassigned while in the Atlantic operation and for </P>
<P>more than sixty (60) hours of his originally scheduled arrival at his home domicile </P>
<P>if reassigned while in the Pacific operation.&nbsp;&nbsp;In the event a pilot is reassigned and </P>
<P>his arrival at his domicile will be later than originally scheduled, upon his request, </P>
<P>the Company shall notify the pilot's residence or contact number of the delay and </P>
<P>expected arrival time.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>The Association will be consulted and their recommendations will be given full</P>
<P>consideration whenever a new aircraft type is ordered which requires on-board </P>
<P>rest facilities as a result of this agreement or the FAR. The present B-747-400 </P>
<P>rest facility is considered to be optimally suited for aircraft operating within the </P>
<P>range of the B-747-400.</P>
<B><P>C</B>. Should a situation arise, either in the country or city served, that could present </P>
<P>a concern for the continued safety of the crew or aircraft, then representatives of </P>
<P>the Association and the Company will meet immediately to determine the most</P>
<P>appropriate action and/or modifications required, including the possibility that</P>
<P>additional insurance may be appropriate. In no event will a pilot assigned to </P>
<P>United's international operations suffer any reduction to his Company insurance </P>
<P>benefits.&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, the Company agrees to protect a pilot from any reduction </P>
<P>in his personal life insurance benefits which may result from his assignment to </P>
<P>international operations at the time of his death up to a maximum of one million </P>
<P>dollars of total personal coverage.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 13 and 20 of the Agreement, any</P>
<P>lineholder who does not fly a scheduled international trip due to a sick leave </P>
<P>absence, is subject to the following:</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D-1- </B>Such pilot shall be eligible to restore all or part of his accrued sick leave</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;used for the illness absence on an actual hour for actual hour basis.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D-2- </B>Restoration of sick leave accrual shall be accomplished by picking up </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;open time under the provisions of Section 20-H-5 of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D-3- </B>Pick up under this provision shall be limited to the month in which the</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;absence occurs.</P>
<B><P>E</B>. Lost Luggage</P>
<P>If a crew member's luggage is lost by the Company while he is assigned an</P>
<P>international trip pairing or assigned to an international TDY domicile, then he </P>
<P>shall be subject to the policy regarding lost luggage applicable to revenue </P>
<P>passengers.&nbsp;&nbsp;An advance of Two Hundred and Fifty Dollars ($250.00) will be </P>
<P>made available to a pilot under these circumstances. Such Two Hundred and </P>
<B><P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 113</P>
</B><P>Fifty Dollars ($250.00) will be returned to the Company if his luggage is </P>
<P>recovered.&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>F. </B>While on layover at a foreign location, crew members shall advise the local </P>
<P>United Station Operations of their whereabouts, if not residing at the scheduled </P>
<P>hotel.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>Should a pilot incur any foreign income tax liability as a result of an involuntary</P>
<P>TDY assignment, that liability will be assumed by the Company.</P>
<B><P>H. </B>Line preferencing information will be made available at one or more locations</P>
<P>where crews layover who are flying trip pairings of five (5) or more days duration.</P>
<P>Schedule preferences will be accepted by telemeter from all such crews who will </P>
<P>not return to their domicile before close of preferencing.</P>
<B><P>I. </B>Should government action modify any existing United Airlines route, the parties </P>
<P>will meet to discuss the possible need to make modifications to this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<B><P>J. </B>The Company will consult with the Association Hotel Committee prior to </P>
<P>changing any currently approved international layover facility. Whenever changes </P>
<P>are contemplated, at the request of the ALPA Hotel Committee Chairman, a</P>
<P>representative of Flight Operations will inspect the proposed facility prior to the</P>
<P>change taking place.</P>
<B><P>K. </B>The Company will provide the names of English speaking doctors and medical</P>
<P>facilities which are available 24 hours. A priority will be placed on finding doctors </P>
<P>and facilities which are convenient to the layover hotel and with whom </P>
<P>arrangements can be made which will eliminate the possibility that the pilot will </P>
<P>be required to provide immediate payment for treatment; including arrangements </P>
<P>which would require the pilot to later reimburse the Company for advancing </P>
<P>payment on his behalf.</P>
<B><P>L. </B>The Company and the Association will conduct a second joint medical study</P>
<P>regarding crew rest. The Company commits that scheduling practices and</P>
<P>philosophies no less favorable to the pilots than those in effect January 15, 1991 </P>
<P>shall remain in effect pending the results of this second crew rest study.</P>
<B><P>M. </B>Should international scheduling problems occur, the parties will meet to </P>
<P>attempt to resolve the problems.&nbsp;&nbsp;Additionally, should the Federal Aviation </P>
<P>Administration modify the current FAR's, the parties will meet for the purpose of </P>
<P>determining what changes, if any, should be made to this International </P>
<P>Supplemental Letter of Agreement to conform with the new regulations.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 114</P>
<P>N. </B>Whenever a new aircraft type is ordered which requires an on-board rest </P>
<P>facility as a result of this Agreement or the FAR, a joint committee comprised of </P>
<P>ALPA and Company representatives will study and review all possible rest </P>
<P>facilities currently in use or in development to determine what best meets the </P>
<P>needs of United and the pilots. The joint committee will make their </P>
<P>recommendation to the MEC Chairman and the Chief Operating Officer for a final </P>
<P>resolution.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION </B>9- DURATION</P>
<P>This Supplemental Agreement shall become effective upon signing and run</P>
<P>concurrently with Section 22 of the 2000 Pilot Agreement.</P>
<P>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have signed this Supplemental Agreement </P>
<P>this 9th day of May, 1991.</P></FONT>

<P>1625 Massachusetts Ave., N.W.</P>
<P>Washington, D.C. 20036</P>
<P>Dear Captain Babbitt:</P>
<P>This will confirm that in the negotiations leading to the 1991 Pilot Agreement, the</P>
<P>Company and the United Airlines' Master Executive Council Negotiating </P>
<P>Committee agreed that prior to implementing any twin engine ETOPS operations </P>
<P>in the Pacific Basin, the parties will meet to review the ETOPS experience gained </P>
<P>in the Atlantic Operation and reach agreement on any changes in the </P>
<P>International Supplemental Agreement necessary to initiate such flying.</P>
<P>It was further agreed that should the Company receive any new European route</P>
<P>authority during the term of the 1991 agreement which could not be operated </P>
<P>under the Atlantic provisions of the International Supplemental Agreement the </P>
<P>parties will promptly meet and agree on such changes in the agreement </P>
<P>necessary to implement such new service. (Such changes could include, but not </P>
<P>be limited to, additional crew augmentation).</P>

<B><P>Page 118</P>
</B><I><P>Future Pension Amendments</P>
</I><P ALIGN="CENTER">LETTER OF AGREEMENT</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">between</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">in the service of</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">as represented by</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION,</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">INTERNATIONAL</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">&nbsp;</P>
<P>THIS LETTER OF AGREEMENT is made and entered into in accordance with </P>
<P>the provisions of the Railway Labor Act, as amended, by and between UNITED </P>
<P>AIR LINES, INC. (hereafter referred to as the "Company") and the AIR LINE </P>
<P>PILOTS in the service of UNITED AIR LINES, INC., as represented by the AIR </P>
<P>LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION INTERNATIONAL (hereinafter referred to as the </P>
<P>"Association").</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">W I T N E S S E T H:</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">WHEREAS, the Company and the Association desire to clarify their respective </P>
<P>rights with respect to future amendments to the United Air Lines, Inc. Pilots Fixed </P>
<P>Benefit Retirement Income Plan (Fixed Plan), the United Air Lines, Inc. Pilots' </P>
<P>Directed Account Retirement Income Plan (Directed Account Plan) and the </P>
<P>Welfare Benefit Plans (any of the above may be referred to herein as a "Plan").</P>
<P>NOW THEREFORE, it is mutually agreed:</P>
<B><P>1</B>. The Company will provide the Association an opportunity to discuss and </P>
<P>comment on all proposed amendments to any provision of the Fixed Plan, </P>
<P>Directed Account Plan, or a Welfare Benefit Plan at least thirty (30) days prior to </P>
<P>implementation.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company will consider any such comments in good faith. If, </P>
<P>after proper notice by the Company, the Association objects to a proposed Plan </P>
<P>amendment, the parties retain all their present rights and arguments under the </P>
<P>Agreement and Plans concerning the Company's ability to implement such an </P>
<P>amendment without approval of the Association.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Notwithstanding the provisions of 1, above, the Company shall not amend any</P>
<P>provision of the Fixed Plan, the Directed Account Plan, or the Welfare Benefit </P>
<P>Plans which changes negotiated benefits without the prior written consent of the</P>
<P>Association. This provision is without prejudice to any other rights of the </P>
<P>Association concerning other amendments to a Plan.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 119</P>
<P>3. </B>The Association may submit any dispute concerning any proposed Plan</P>
<P>amendment, directly to the System Board or Pension Board, as applicable, within</P>
<P>seven (7) days from the date the dispute is known to exist and will be decided </P>
<P>within 60 days of submission.</P>
<P>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have executed this Letter of Agreement </P>
<P>this 9<SUP>th</SUP> day of May, 1991.</P></FONT>

<B><P>Page 120</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<I><P>CRAF</P>
</I><P ALIGN="CENTER">SUPPLEMENTAL AGREEMENT</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">between</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">and</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">in the service of</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">as represented by</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION,</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">INTERNATIONAL</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>THIS SUPPLEMENTAL AGREEMENT, is made and entered into in accordance </P>
<P>with the provisions of Title II of the Railway Labor Act, as amended, by and </P>
<P>between UNITED AIR LINES, INC. (hereinafter referred to as the "Company") and THE AIR LINE PILOTS in the service of UNITED AIR LINES, INC., as </P>
<P>represented by the AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION, INTERNATIONAL </P>
<P>(hereinafter referred to as the "Association").</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">W I T N E S S E T H:</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the Company and the Association desire to supplement their Pilots'</P>
<P>Employment Agreement signed May 9, 1991, (hereinafter referred to as the</P>
<P>"Agreement") by providing certain rates of compensation, rules and working</P>
<P>conditions with respect to the Company's CRAF Operation (Civil Reserve Air </P>
<P>Fleet).</P>
<P>NOW, THEREFORE, it is mutually agreed and understood by and between the </P>
<P>parties of this Supplemental Agreement that the rates of compensation, rules and </P>
<P>working conditions stipulated herein shall be in full force and effect on the </P>
<P>Company's Civil Reserve Air Fleet Operation; provided that all provisions of the </P>
<P>Agreement, as herein defined, except as specifically modified or excepted by this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement, shall be applicable also to the Company's Civil </P>
<P>Reserve Air Fleet Operation.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 1</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">DEFINITIONS</P>
<B><P>A. </B>The word "Agreement" when used in this Supplemental Agreement means the</P>
<P>Agreement between United Air Lines, Inc. and the Air Line Pilots in the service of</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 121</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>United Air Lines, Inc., as represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, </P>
<P>International, signed August 14, 1981, or as it may be amended or modified.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>The term "CRAF Operation" for the purpose of this Supplemental Agreement</P>
<P>means all flight operations conducted in accordance with the agreement between</P>
<P>United Air Lines and the Department of Defense but shall not include the </P>
<P>Company's certificated service or commercial charter service or any other </P>
<P>government operation.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 2</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">COMPENSATION</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">Rates of Pay</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>Pilots while assigned to the CRAF Operation shall be paid in accordance</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;with the applicable rates of pay for the type of equipment flown as provided in</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Section 3 of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>In addition to the compensation specified in Paragraph A-1 above, pilots</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;shall be paid the rate of Twelve Dollars and Fifty Cents ($12.50) for each hour</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;flown.</P>
<P>Hourly Pay Computation</P>
<P>Actual time block-to-block shall be used in computing the override pay as </P>
<P>specified in Paragraph A-2 above for flying performed on the CRAF Operation.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 3</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">EXPENSES</P>
<B><P>A. </B>Pilots when on a CRAF Operation shall be entitled to expense reimbursement</P>
<P>under the provisions of Section 4 of the Agreement. Accommodations provided </P>
<P>by the Company, where available, will conform to the minimum standards set </P>
<P>forth in Section 4 of the Agreement. In addition to the hourly expenses provided </P>
<P>by Section 4-A-1 of the Agreement, pilots in a CRAF operation shall receive an </P>
<P>additional $.50 an hour.</P>
<B><P>B</B>. Travel expenses en route for the pilot while commuting to and from the </P>
<P>Operation shall be allowed in accordance with this Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 122</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 4</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">MOVING EXPENSES</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">No pilot shall be required to move to the location of the CRAF assignment, </P>
<P>unless required by the government. No moving expenses shall be paid until a </P>
<P>pilot has completed ninety (90) days from the date of the CRAF vacancy.&nbsp;&nbsp;All </P>
<P>moving shall be in accordance with Section 10 of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 5</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">FILLING OF VACANCIES</P>
<P>In anticipation of the emergency nature of the CRAF Operation, the Company </P>
<P>shall keep on file a currently effective Preference List which shall include, in order </P>
<P>of seniority, all pilots desiring to fly the CRAF Operation. Each pilot on the CRAF</P>
<P>Preference List shall indicate whether he is preferencing a Captain vacancy, a </P>
<P>First Officer vacancy or a Second Officer vacancy, and equipment type.&nbsp;&nbsp;This List </P>
<P>shall be kept up to date by repreferencing on June 1st of every year.&nbsp;&nbsp;Any pilot </P>
<P>preferencing a CRAF assignment must be currently status (Captain, First Officer </P>
<P>or Second Officer) and equipment type qualified.&nbsp;&nbsp;If the Company commits an </P>
<P>entire fleet to the CRAF Agreement, then any vacancies posted for that fleet will </P>
<P>be considered as CRAF vacancies also. Any pilot awarded an assignment under </P>
<P>these circumstances will be considered as having also been awarded a CRAF </P>
<P>assignment.&nbsp;&nbsp;A pilot may remove his name from the CRAF Preference List at any </P>
<P>time by giving thirty (30) days written notification to his Flight Manager, except </P>
<P>when such pilot holds an assignment in an equipment type which has been </P>
<P>totally committed to the CRAF Operation.</P>
<B><P>A</B>. All pilot vacancies on the Company's CRAF Operation shall be filled in </P>
<P>Accordance with system seniority provided such pilot is status and equipment </P>
<P>qualified.&nbsp;&nbsp;In the event there are insufficient bidders, the Company will assign the </P>
<P>most junior status and equipment qualified pilot on the system.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>All CRAF vacancies shall be bulletined on a systemwide basis.</P>
<B><P>C</B>. A pilot while assigned to the Company's CRAF Operation shall be permitted to </P>
<P>bid on any vacancies. Every reasonable effort shall be made to advise all CRAF </P>
<P>pilots of all bulletined vacancies.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>In the event that there is a reduction in the number of personnel on the CRAF</P>
<P>Operation, the reduction shall be in the reverse order of seniority in the status </P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 123</P>
</B><P>and equipment affected at the domicile where the reduction occurs, unless a </P>
<P>more senior pilot at such domicile in the status and equipment affected </P>
<P>volunteers to return to line flying duty for United Air Lines, Inc.&nbsp;&nbsp;All pilots referred </P>
<P>to in this Paragraph shall have the rights specified in Paragraph F below.</P>
<B><P>E</B>. Notwithstanding Paragraph 8-C of Section 8 of the Agreement, a pilot's </P>
<P>assignment on the domestic operation shall not be considered as vacated and </P>
<P>such assignment shall not be bid or filled for a period of ninety (90) days </P>
<P>following the date of the award of his CRAF vacancy. In the event a pilot is </P>
<P>relieved of his CRAF assignment during this ninety (90) day period, such pilot </P>
<P>shall resume his last previously held domestic assignment.</P>
<B><P>F. </B>A pilot returning to line flying duties on the domestic operation shall have the </P>
<P>rights specified in the applicable provisions of Paragraph 8-D, 8-E, 8-G, 8-H, 8-I </P>
<P>and 8-K-2 of Section 8 of the Agreement, but shall not be entitled to a Company </P>
<P>paid move unless the move is required by the government. In addition, pilots </P>
<P>reduced in accordance with Paragraph D above may bump the most junior pilot </P>
<P>in any status or equipment at any CRAF domicile provided the pilot so bumping </P>
<P>is status and equipment qualified.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>A pilot's initial assignment to the CRAF Operation shall be in accordance with</P>
<P>system seniority of those pilots on the Preference List. A pilot's assignment to the</P>
<P>Company's CRAF Operation will be effective on the date which appears on the </P>
<P>award of such vacancy. Assignment to the CRAF Operation will be made on the </P>
<P>basis of the chronological order of the award dates.</P>
<B><P>H. </B>Any pilot assigned or awarded a bid on the CRAF Operation must take up </P>
<P>such assignment or bid on the date specified by the Company.</P>
<B><P>I</B>. Notwithstanding the provisions of Paragraph 8-K-2 of Section 8 of the </P>
<P>Agreement, a pilot on the domestic operation may not displace a pilot holding a </P>
<P>CRAF assignment.</P>
<B><P>J. </B>During the period in which a pilot has been released from his CRAF </P>
<P>assignment and pending the exercise of his bumping rights as provided in this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement, he shall, notwithstanding the provisions of Paragraph </P>
<P>8-K-1 and 8-K-3 of Section 8, take up duties of Captain, First Officer or Second </P>
<P>Officer at the United Air Lines, Inc. domicile having his equipment type nearest to </P>
<P>his CRAF assignment domicile or his residence.</P>
<B><P>K. </B>A pilot's release from assignment to the Company's CRAF Operation will be</P>
<P>effective from the date he is assigned to the domestic operation, which shall be </P>
<P>after a reasonable rest period after his last trip of not less than two (2) calendar </P>
<P>days.&nbsp;&nbsp;Such rest period shall be exclusive of travel time required to return to the </P>
<P>pilot's domicile.</P>
<B><P>Page 124</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 6</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">VACATIONS</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">A</B>. Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 11 of the Agreement, a pilot </P>
<P>assigned to the Company's CRAF Operation shall receive three and two-thirds </P>
<P>(3-2/3) days vacation credit for each calendar month of service on such operation </P>
<P>which shall be cumulative and carried over to the Company's domestic operation </P>
<P>and made a part of the regular annual vacation credit due such pilot.&nbsp;&nbsp;In </P>
<P>computing vacation accrual, a pilot who was assigned to the Company's CRAF </P>
<P>Operation for one-half (1/2) or more of a calendar month will be credited with </P>
<P>three and two-thirds (3-2/3) days vacation for that month. In determining the </P>
<P>vacation credit of a pilot who was assigned to the CRAF Operation, such days </P>
<P>shall be in addition to the prorated vacation credit earned in accordance with </P>
<P>Section 11 of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>B</B>. Vacation periods will be assigned by the Company taking the pilot's </P>
<P>preference and seniority into consideration consistent with the needs of the </P>
<P>CRAF Operation.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 7</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">RETIREMENT BENEFITS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">A pilot assigned to the Company's CRAF Operation will be eligible for continued</P>
<P>participation in the United Air Lines, Inc. Pension Plan for pilots. Contributions on</P>
<P>behalf of a participant shall be based on his earnings while assigned to the</P>
<P>Company's CRAF Operation.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 8</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">DEATH BENEFITS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">In the event of the death of any pilot while assigned to the CRAF Operation or in </P>
<P>the event of death of any pilot resulting from injury or disease received while </P>
<P>assigned to the CRAF Operation, the Company shall pay or cause to be paid, </P>
<P>subject to the conditions of Section 14 of this Supplemental Agreement, </P>
<P>$150,000.00 to the beneficiary or beneficiaries in the order and manner named in </P>
<P>the last Group Life Insurance certificate issued for such pilot as a Company </P>
<P>employee.&nbsp;&nbsp;Such death benefit shall be paid either in a lump sum or in </P>
<P>installments, as the respective pilot's may in writing direct. Such benefits shall be </P>
<P>in addition to the benefits prescribed in the Company's Group Life Insurance and </P>
<P>Group Accident-Sickness Insurance Program as per the Basic Agreement.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 125</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">&nbsp;</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 9</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SICKNESS AND INJURY BENEFITS</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">A. </B>A pilot assigned to the Company's CRAF Operation shall receive sickness and</P>
<P>injury benefits in the same manner as any pilot as outlined in Section 13 of the</P>
<P>Agreement.</P>
<B><P>B</B>. A pilot assigned to the Company's CRAF Operation will be eligible for </P>
<P>continued participation and coverage in the Company's Accident and Sickness </P>
<P>Program as provided in the Basic Agreement.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 10</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">PERMANENT TOTAL DISABILITY</P>
<P>In lieu of death benefits described in Section 8, in the event of the permanent </P>
<P>total disability of a pilot resulting from injury or disease received while assigned to </P>
<P>the CRAF Operation, the Company shall pay or cause to be paid, subject to the </P>
<P>conditions of Section 14 of this Supplemental Agreement, compensation in the </P>
<P>sum of $150,000.00. Such compensation shall be paid either in a lump sum or in </P>
<P>installments, as the respective pilots may in writing direct.&nbsp;&nbsp; The loss of, or the </P>
<P>loss of use of, both hands, or both arms, or both feet, or both legs, or both eyes, </P>
<P>or any two thereof, shall constitute permanent total disability for the purpose of </P>
<P>this Section. In all other cases under this Section, permanent total disability shall </P>
<P>be determined in accordance with the facts.&nbsp;&nbsp;Such benefit shall be in addition to </P>
<P>the benefits prescribed in the Company's Group Life Insurance and Cooperative </P>
<P>Group Life and Group Accident-Sickness Insurance Program as per the Basic </P>
<P>Agreement.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 126</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 11</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">INSURANCE AND WELFARE BENEFITS</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">A. </B>Any pilot assigned to fly a CRAF flight shall continue to receive full benefits as</P>
<P>provided in each applicable Plan. Further, the war limitation will be waived and</P>
<P>benefits will be payable in the event of claims arising out of a declared or </P>
<P>undeclared war. Benefits under all plans shall be paid on a per capita basis with </P>
<P>no tartrate per accident limit.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>Life Insurance</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1-a- </B>Company Paid Life - $80,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1-b- </B>Supplemental Life up to $330,000 (Pilot Contributor)</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1-c- </B>CRAF Life - $150,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>Accidental Death and Dismemberment (AD&amp;D)</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2-a- </B>Company Paid - $4,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2-b- </B>Company Paid (Pilot) - $35,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2-c- </B>Supplemental (24 Hour High Limit Contributory) - Up to $300,000.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-3- </B>CRAF Death and Dismemberment - $150,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-4- </B>Special Hazards Benefits - $100,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-5- </B>Invalidated Life Benefit - $50,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-6- </B>Personal Life Insurance Protection - Up to $1,000,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-7- </B>Pilots Disability Income Benefit - 55% of Considered Compensation.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-8- </B>To the extent they are present in the Company's insurance programs, all</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;exclusions and limitations in coverage, such as for job-related injury and </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;criminal acts, are waived for pilots while participating in any operation </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;conducted under the provisions of this Letter.&nbsp;&nbsp;The limitation for self inflicted </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;injury will remain in effect.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-9- </B>The Company will protect a pilot from any reduction in his personal life</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;insurance benefits which may result from his assignment to international </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CRAF operations at the time of his death up to a maximum of one million </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;dollars of total personal coverage.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 127</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 12</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">WORKMEN'S COMPENSATION BENEFITS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">The Workmen's Compensation Benefits provided for pilots by Section 15 of the</P>
<P>Agreement shall be provided for all pilots assigned to the Company's CRAF </P>
<P>Operation and all amounts paid under such Section shall be in addition to any </P>
<P>amounts paid under Section 8 and 10 of this Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 13</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">MISSING, INTERNMENT, PRISONER OF WAR - BENEFITS</P>
<B><P>A. </B>Captains, First Officers and Second Officers who while engaged in the CRAF</P>
<P>Operation are interned or taken prisoner of war by a foreign government shall be</P>
<P>entitled to compensation at the salary as specified in Section 2 of this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement for the periods during which they are interned or held </P>
<P>prisoner of war; provided, however, that in the absence of knowledge on the part </P>
<P>of the Company as to whether a pilot is alive or dead, compensation in such </P>
<P>amounts will be allowed for a period of twelve (12) months after such Captain, </P>
<P>First Officer of Second Officer was last known to the Company to have been </P>
<P>interned or held prisoner of war.</P>
<B><P>B</B>. When after such twelve (12) month period it has still not been established </P>
<P>whether</P>
<P>such pilots are alive or dead, Captains, First Officers and Second Officers shall </P>
<P>be allowed compensation at the salary as specified in Section 2 of this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement from and after such twelve (12) month period until </P>
<P>death is established or until there is a sufficient presumption of death to permit </P>
<P>payment of the death benefit provided in Section 8.</P>
<B><P>C</B>. In the event such Captain, First Officer or Second Officer is later found to be </P>
<P>alive, he shall receive retroactively the difference in pay between the total </P>
<P>compensation (including death benefit) paid by the Company under this Section </P>
<P>and the monthly amounts which would have been paid under Paragraph A of this </P>
<P>Section and such monthly pay shall then be resumed for the duration of </P>
<P>internment or imprisonment.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>Captains, First Officers and Second Officers who while engaged in the CRAF</P>
<P>Operation become missing and whose whereabouts become unknown shall be</P>
<P>allowed compensation at the salary as specified in Section 2 of this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement for a period of twelve (12) months after disappearance </P>
<P>or until such date as death is established, whichever first occurs.&nbsp;&nbsp;If upon the </P>
<P>expiration of the twelve (12) month period, any such Captain, First Officer or </P>
<B><P>Page 128</P>
</B><P>Second Officer is still missing and his whereabouts is unknown, or if prior to that </P>
<P>time his death is established, the Company shall pay the death benefit provided </P>
<P>for in Section 8. </P>
<B><P>E</B>. The monthly compensation allowable under this Section to pilots interned, </P>
<P>held prisoner of war, or missing shall be credited to such pilot on the books of the</P>
<P>Company and shall be disbursed by the Company in accordance with written</P>
<P>directions from such pilots.&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company shall cause each pilot hereafter </P>
<P>employed in or assigned to its CRAF Operation to execute and deliver to the </P>
<P>Company prior to such employment or assignment a written direction in the form </P>
<P>set forth in Section 16 of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>F. </B>Any payments due to any pilots under this Section which are not covered by a</P>
<P>written direction as above required shall be held by the Company for such pilot </P>
<P>and in the event of his death shall be paid to the legal representative of his </P>
<P>estate.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>The monthly compensation allowable under this Section shall be in lieu of all</P>
<P>compensation provided for by any law in respect to persons interned, held </P>
<P>prisoner of war or missing and shall also be in lieu of all salary, expenses and </P>
<P>subsistence during the period in which a pilot is interned, held prisoner of war or </P>
<P>missing.</P>
<B><P>H. </B>Pilots shall maintain and continue to accrue seniority and longevity for pay</P>
<P>purposes during periods in which they are interned, held prisoner of war or </P>
<P>missing.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 14</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">GENERAL CONDITIONS</P>
<B><P>A</B>. The provisions for death benefits in Section 8 and for disability benefits in </P>
<P>Section 10 and 11 are intended to apply to Captains, First Officers and Second </P>
<P>Officers while assigned to the CRAF Operation, as follows:</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>When outside the continental United States in connection with or as a </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;result of said operations irrespective of whether they are actually engaged in </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;active duty at the time of death or injury.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>When within the continental United States only if they are actually </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;engaged in the course of employment at the time of death or injury, except that </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;when not actually engaged in the course of employment at the time of death or </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;injury, Captains, First Officers and Second Officers receive the group </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;insurance benefits as per the Basic Agreement.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 129</P>
<P>B</B>. The obligation of the Company to make any payment provided for in Section </P>
<P>11 and 12 hereof is subject to the condition that the injury or disease resulting in </P>
<P>the permanent total or partial disability shall not have been occasioned solely by </P>
<P>his attempted suicide.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 15</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">A. </B>Rules governing hours of service during the first thirty (30) days of the CRAF</P>
<P>Operation shall be those specified in the applicable FAR's. At the termination of </P>
<P>the initial thirty (30) day period or as soon as feasible, the hours of service as </P>
<P>specified in the Basic Agreement or Supplemental Agreements as applicable.</P>
<B><P>B</B>. Other than as specifically provided in this Supplemental Agreement, the </P>
<P>provisions of the Basic Agreement shall apply.</P>
<B><P>C. </B>The assignment of all pilots to this Operation will be in writing to the pilot.</P>
<B><P>D</B>. Pilots will continue to fly any CRAF flight deemed essential to the national </P>
<P>defense provided such flights are solely military in nature and carry cargo </P>
<P>composed entirely of military requirements even if at the time such military flights </P>
<P>are necessary the pilots have withdrawn their air line service for any </P>
<P>reason.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>D-1- </B>To assure the movement of a particular flight under such circumstances, </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;the Association will require certification by an appropriate Company official </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;designated by the Company that such flight is in accordance with the </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;specifications set forth in Paragraph D above.&nbsp;&nbsp;This certification shall be </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;provided prior to movement of the flight where feasible or, where not feasible, </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;promptly thereafter.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;D-2- </B>Pilots who fly such military traffic will not lose any benefits accruing to </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;other pilots which they would otherwise have received upon settlement of an </P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;unresolved labor dispute.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 130</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 16</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">DURATION</P>
<P>This Supplemental Agreement shall become effective on the date of signing and </P>
<P>shall remain in full force and effect and shall run concurrently with the Agreement </P>
<P>signed August 14, 1981.</P>
<P>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have signed this Supplemental Agreement this 9th day of May, 1991.</P></FONT>

<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P ALIGN="RIGHT">Page 131</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<I><P>MAC</P>
</I><P ALIGN="CENTER">MAC SUPPLEMENTAL AGREEMENT</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">between</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">and</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">in the service of</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">as represented by</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION,</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">INTERNATIONAL</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THIS SUPPLEMENTAL AGREEMENT is made and entered into in accordance </P>
<P>with the provisions of Title II of the Railway Labor Act, as amended, by and </P>
<P>between UNITED AIR LINES, INC. (hereinafter referred to as the "Company") </P>
<P>and the AIR LINE PILOTS in the service of UNITED AIR LINES, INC. as </P>
<P>represented by the AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION, INTERNATIONAL </P>
<P>(hereinafter referred to as the "Association").</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">W I T N E S S E T H:</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">&nbsp;</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the Company and the Association desire to supplement their Pilots'</P>
<P>Employment Agreement, signed May 9, 1991, (hereinafter referred to as the</P>
<P>"Agreement") by providing certain rates of compensation, rules and working</P>
<P>conditions with respect to the Company's "MAC Operation" (Military Airlift </P>
<P>Command).&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>NOW, THEREFORE, it is mutually agreed and understood by and between the </P>
<P>parties of this Supplemental Agreement that the rates of compensation, rules and </P>
<P>working conditions stipulated herein shall be in full force and effect on the </P>
<P>Company's Military Airlift Command Operation provided that all provisions of the </P>
<P>Agreement, as herein defined, except as specifically modified or excepted by this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement shall be applicable also to the Company's Military Airlift </P>
<P>Command Operation.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 1</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">DEFINITIONS</P>
<B><P>A. </B>The word "Agreement" when used in this Supplemental Agreement means the</P>
<P>Agreement between United Air Lines, Inc. and the Air Line Pilots in the service </P>
<B><P>Page 132</P>
</B><P>of United Air Lines, Inc., as represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, </P>
<P>International, signed June 15, 1985 or as it is amended or modified.</P>
<B><P>B</B>. The term "MAC Operation" for the purpose of this Supplemental Agreement </P>
<P>Means any flights all or part of which are conducted in accordance with any </P>
<P>contract made between United Air Lines, Inc. and the Military Airlift Command </P>
<P>into a non-conflict area.</P>
<P>The term "Critical MAC Operation" for the purpose of this Supplemental </P>
<P>Agreement means any flights, regardless of the nature of payload transported, all </P>
<P>or part of which are conducted in accordance with any contract made between </P>
<P>United Air Lines, Inc. and the Military Airlift Command into an area of the world </P>
<P>where an armed conflict is occurring or has occurred within the prior thirty (30) </P>
<P>days.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>"MAC Operation Base" is the domicile or geographical location to which</P>
<P>responsibility is assigned and pilot vacancies are bid for the conduct of the </P>
<P>Critical MAC Operations when the level of critical MAC flying is planned to be </P>
<P>nine hundred and seventy-five (975) hours or more per month and is planned to </P>
<P>exist for sixty (60) days or more.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 2</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">MAC FLYING</P>
<B><P>A. </B>Critical MAC flying into non-conflict areas will be done by a domicile where </P>
<P>Pilots are currently assigned to the equipment used.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>MAC flying of a non-critical nature will be assigned under the applicable</P>
<P>provisions of Section 20 of the Pilots Agreement and/or the Charter </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>MAC flying which is defined as "Critical MAC Operations" will be </P>
<P>assigned to volunteer pilots from among the pilots assigned a reserve line. </P>
<P>Should insufficient pilots volunteer, reserve pilots may be assigned in inverse </P>
<P>order of seniority.</P>
<P>Critical MAC flying, if planned for nine hundred and seventy-five (975) hours </P>
<P>Per month or more, and if planned to exist for sixty (60) days or more will be </P>
<P>flown by a MAC Operation Base as defined in Paragraph 1-D above, provided at </P>
<P>least ninety (90) days notice is available to the Company.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 133</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 3</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">FILLING OF VACANCIES</P>
<B><P>A. </B>Bidding Of Critical MAC Vacancies</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>All pilot vacancies on the Company's Critical MAC Operation shall be</P>
<P>bulletined at all domiciles as far in advance as possible but not later than thirty </P>
<P>(30) days after such vacancy exists. If at the time of advertising a critical MAC </P>
<P>vacancy, the Company plans to advertise a domestic vacancy in the same status </P>
<P>and equipment type as the critical MAC vacancy and with an advertised effective </P>
<P>date the same as or prior to the critical MAC vacancy, the domestic vacancy will </P>
<P>be advertised and awarded prior to the awarding of the critical MAC vacancy.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>Vacancy bulletins for critical MAC assignments shall state the number </P>
<P>and status of vacancies to be filled; the anticipated effective date of the </P>
<P>assignment; the equipment type involved; the Critical MAC Operation Base; the </P>
<P>anticipated general area of operation; and a reasonable deadline date, not less </P>
<P>than ten (10) days, after which bids will not be considered.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-3- </B>All critical MAC vacancies shall be filled in accordance with system </P>
<P>Seniority from among eligible bidders as stipulated in Paragraph F of this </P>
<P>Section.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>Eligibility To Be Awarded Critical MAC Vacancies</P>
<P>A pilot's eligibility to be awarded a critical MAC vacancy shall be subject to the</P>
<P>following conditions:</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;B-1- </B>He must be currently flying in the status and equipment type of the </P>
<P>Critical MAC assignment at the time of the closing of the critical MAC vacancy </P>
<P>bulletin, or</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;B-2- </B>He must have been awarded a domestic vacancy in the status and</P>
<P>equipment type of the critical MAC vacancy which had an advertised effective </P>
<P>date the same as or prior to the advertised effective date of the critical MAC</P>
<P>assignment.</P>
<B><P>C. </B>Any pilot assigned to the Critical MAC Operation may bid and be awarded a</P>
<P>domestic vacancy under the provisions of the Agreement and shall be </P>
<P>considered to have vacated his former domestic assignment at the time the flying </P>
<P>for such awarded assignment commences. Such pilot shall not be required to </P>
<P>occupy his new domestic assignment until he vacates his critical MAC assignment, unless such new assignment involves a change in status or </P>
<P>equipment type in which case he shall be required to occupy such new domicile </P>
<P>assignment.</P>
<B><P>Page 134</P>
<P>D. </B>Whenever a pilot for any reason vacates his critical MAC assignment, he shall</P>
<P>return to his current domestic assignment.</P>
<B><P>E. </B>Section 8-K of the Agreement shall not apply to pilots in the Critical MAC </P>
<P>Operation in the event of a reduction in the number of assignments on critical </P>
<P>MAC. In the event of a reduction of domestic assignments affecting a critical </P>
<P>MAC pilot's domestic assignment, Section 8-K shall apply. Notwithstanding </P>
<P>Section 8-K, a domestic pilot who loses his assignment shall not be permitted to </P>
<P>bump into the Critical MAC Operation.</P>
<B><P>F.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;F-1- </B>A pilot may vacate an assignment on the Critical MAC Operation by </P>
<P>Giving notice in writing to the Company of his desire to return to his domestic </P>
<P>assignment. The Company shall release such pilot as soon as possible but in </P>
<P>any event he shall be returned to his domestic assignment on the first day of the </P>
<P>calendar month following the completion of sixty (60) days from the date of </P>
<P>receipt by the Company of the pilot's request for release.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;F-2- </B>A pilot who has vacated his critical MAC assignment under the </P>
<P>provisions of sub-paragraph 1 above may not be awarded a critical MAC </P>
<P>assignment for a period of six (6) months following the date of his release from </P>
<P>such critical MAC assignment, except that a pilot who has vacated his critical </P>
<P>MAC assignment to take up a new domestic assignment involving a change in </P>
<P>status, as provided in Section 3-C of this Supplemental Agreement, who is </P>
<P>subsequently reduced from such assignment and bumps into critical MAC </P>
<P>equipment type shall, notwithstanding said six (6) months restriction, be eligible </P>
<P>to bid a critical MAC vacancy.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>When at the request of a pilot the Company adjudges that unusual conditions </P>
<P>Exist concerning his assignment to the Critical MAC Operation, such pilot shall </P>
<P>be allowed to return to his domestic assignment within thirty (30) days of the </P>
<P>acknowledgement of the unusual condition.</P>
<B><P>H. </B>Standby Assignments To Critical MAC Operation</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-1- </B>In addition to the number of pilot assignments provided for under the</P>
<P>provisions of Paragraph A and B above, the Company shall advertise and award</P>
<P>critical MAC standby assignments in each pilot status to the extent necessary to</P>
<P>provide adequate coverage of increases in the monthly level of flying on the</P>
<P>Critical MAC Operation.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 135</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-2- </B>A pilot who holds a standby assignment shall acquire the necessary</P>
<P>over water and immunization qualification in order to be available for short notice</P>
<P>assignment to the Critical MAC Operation. A pilot holding said standby </P>
<P>assignment shall continue to serve in his normal assignment in the domestic </P>
<P>operation until such time as he is moved into the Critical MAC Operation to </P>
<P>alleviate a temporary need contemplated to exist for less than sixty (60) days in </P>
<P>the pilot status in which he holds a standby assignment.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-3- </B>Pilots holding a standby assignment, when needed to fill a temporary</P>
<P>requirement shall be assigned to the Critical MAC Operation in order of seniority</P>
<P>among those pilots holding standby assignments in each pilot status. Upon</P>
<P>termination of the temporary need on the Critical MAC Operation, pilots holding</P>
<P>standby assignments shall be released from the Critical MAC Operation in </P>
<P>reverse order of seniority and will return to their normal domestic assignment and </P>
<P>critical MAC standby assignment.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-4- </B>Pilots holding a standby assignment who are assigned to the Critical </P>
<P>MAC Operation for all or part of the month shall be required to state their </P>
<P>preference under the provisions of Section 20-D of the Agreement in their </P>
<P>domestic assignment for the following month. If more than one (1) standby pilot is </P>
<P>assigned to the Critical MAC Operation for a portion of a given month, such </P>
<P>standby pilots shall be assigned available lines of flying in accordance with their </P>
<P>seniority and preference after all pilots holding regular critical MAC assignments </P>
<P>have been awarded their schedule preference.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-5- </B>A standby pilot assigned to fly a Critical MAC Operation trip shall, upon</P>
<P>completion of his assignment and return to his domicile, be entitled to not less </P>
<P>than.<B> </B>two (2) calendar days off if his domestic schedule does not provide such </P>
<P>calendar days off. If providing such two (2) calendar days off does not provide </P>
<P>him with a minimum twelve (12) calendar days off for the month, the additional </P>
<P>calendar days off to provide such minimum will be added to the two (2) calendar </P>
<P>days off period.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-5-a- </B>A critical MAC standby pilot will be considered unavailable for</P>
<P>assignment to the Critical MAC Operation trip if such assignment occurs at a</P>
<P>time which precludes providing him with the above required minimum twelve</P>
<P>(12) days off in the month involved.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-6- </B>A critical MAC standby pilot may vacate such assignment in the same</P>
<P>manner as provided in Section 3-C and 3-G of this Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;H-7- </B>A critical MAC standby pilot will vacate such assignment whenever he is</P>
<P>activated in a domestic assignment involving a different status or equipment type</P>
<P>than that of his critical MAC standby assignment.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 136</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>I. </B>It is mutually agreed that regular and standby vacancies for critical MAC </P>
<P>Captains, First Officers and Second Officers shall be posted for bid and award at </P>
<P>the Critical MAC Operation Base(s) as designated by the Company. Such </P>
<P>bidding and awarding, including the determination of the level of regular critical </P>
<P>MAC vacancies, shall be in accordance with the provisions of this Section 3. It is </P>
<P>understood that critical MAC standby vacancies may be bid prior to the time that </P>
<P>regular vacancies are required to be bid in accordance with Section 3 and that a </P>
<P>pilot may hold more than one Critical MAC Operation Base standby vacancy at </P>
<P>the same time.</P>
<B><P>J. </B>In the event there is a reduction in the number of critical MAC assignments, </P>
<P>The Company shall give not less than thirty (30) days notice to the affected pilots </P>
<P>and they shall return to their domestic assignment, in inverse order of seniority.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 4</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">COMPENSATION</P>
<P>In addition to the compensation as provided in Section 3 of the Basic </P>
<P>Agreement, any pilot who flies a critical MAC trip will be paid an override of </P>
<P>Twelve Dollars and Fifty Cents ($12.50) for each hour flown.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 5</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">HOURS OF SERVICE</P>
<P>Due to the operational problems associated with the MAC Operation, such </P>
<P>Flights shall be operated in accordance with the applicable provisions of the </P>
<P>Charter Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 6</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">EXPENSES</P>
<P>Pilots performing an international MAC assignment will be paid expenses </P>
<P>according to Section 4-A of the Agreement, plus an additional $.50 per hour.</P>
<P>In addition to the expenses provided in A above, pilots on a MAC assignment </P>
<P>shall be provided necessary lodging and related ground transportation; or, when </P>
<P>not furnished by the Company, will be reimbursed for reasonable, actual </P>
<P>expenses incurred for lodging and ground transportation.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 137</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>C.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C-1- </B>Transportation to and from a pilot's home domicile to the point of </P>
<P>departure of the MAC trip shall be furnished by the Company. Transportation </P>
<P>over the Company's routes shall be as NRPS or OMC at the pilot's option.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C-2- </B>Transportation of the pilot on any airline other than United will be by First</P>
<P>Class accommodations if domestic or Business Class accommodations if</P>
<P>international, when available.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>Should isolated cases of unusual expenses be encountered by a pilot which </P>
<P>The expense allowance will not normally cover and which were not contemplated </P>
<P>by the provisions of this Supplemental Agreement, the Company will reimburse </P>
<P>the pilot for such expenses upon receipt of a documented Company expense </P>
<P>form.</P>
<B><P>E. </B>In the event a Critical MAC Operation Base is established, travel expenses en</P>
<P>route for the pilot while commuting to and from the operation shall be allowed.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 7</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">DEATH BENEFITS</P>
<P>In the event of the death of any pilot while assigned to the MAC Operation or in </P>
<P>the event of death of any pilot resulting from injury or disease received while </P>
<P>assigned to the MAC Operation, the Company shall pay or cause to be paid, </P>
<P>subject to the conditions of Section 10 of this Supplemental Agreement, </P>
<P>$150,000 to the beneficiary or beneficiaries in the order and manner named in </P>
<P>the last Group Life Insurance certificate issued for such pilot as a Company </P>
<P>employee. Such death benefit shall be paid either in a lump sum or in </P>
<P>installments, as the respective pilots' may in writing direct. Such benefits shall be </P>
<P>in addition to the benefits prescribed in the Company's Group Life Insurance and </P>
<P>Group Accident-Sickness Insurance Program.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 8</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">INSURANCE AND WELFARE BENEFITS</P>
<B><P>A. </B>Any pilot assigned to fly a MAC flight shall continue to receive full benefits as</P>
<P>provided in each applicable Plan. Further, the war limitation will be waived </P>
<P>and.<B> </B>benefits will be payable in the event of claims arising out of a declared or </P>
<P>undeclared war. Benefits under all plans shall be paid on a per capita basis with </P>
<P>no aggregate per accident limit.</P>
<B><P>Page 138</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>Life Insurance</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1-a- </B>Company Paid Life - $80,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1-b- </B>Supplemental Life up to $330,000 (Pilot Contributor)</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1-c- </B>MAC Life - $150,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>Accidental Death and Dismemberment (AD&amp;D)</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2-a- </B>Company Paid - $4,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2-b- </B>Company Paid (Pilot) - $35,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2-c- </B>Supplemental (24 Hour High Limit Contributory) - Up to $300,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-3- </B>MAC Death and Dismemberment - $150,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-4- </B>Special Hazards Benefits - $100,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-5- </B>Invalidated Life Benefit - $50,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-6- </B>Personal Life Insurance Protection - Up to $1,000,000</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-7- </B>Pilots Disability Income Benefit - 55% of Considered Compensation</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-8- </B>To the extent they are present in the Company's insurance programs, all</P>
<P>exclusions and limitations in coverage, such as for job-related injury and criminal</P>
<P>acts, are waived for pilots while participating in any operation conducted under </P>
<P>the provisions of this Letter. the limitation for self inflicted injury will remain in </P>
<P>effect.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-9- </B>The Company will protect a pilot from any reduction in his personal life</P>
<P>insurance benefits which may result from his assignment to international MAC</P>
<P>operations at the time of his death up to a maximum of one million dollars of total</P>
<P>personal coverage.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>In lieu of death benefits described in Section 7 of this Supplemental </P>
<P>Agreement, in the event of the permanent total disability of a pilot resulting from </P>
<P>injury or disease received while assigned to the MAC Operation, the Company </P>
<P>shall pay or cause to be paid, subject to the conditions of Section 10 of this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement, compensation in the sum of $150,000. Such </P>
<P>compensation shall be paid either in a lump sum or in installments, as the </P>
<B><P>Page 139</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>respective pilots may in writing direct. The loss of, or the loss of use of, both </P>
<P>hands, or both arms, or both feet, or both legs, or both eyes, or any two thereof, </P>
<P>shall constitute permanent total disability for the purpose of this Section. In all </P>
<P>other cases under this Section, permanent total disability shall be determined in </P>
<P>accordance with the facts. Such benefit shall be in addition to the benefits </P>
<P>prescribed in the Company's Group Life Insurance and Cooperative Group</P>
<P>Life and Group Accident-Sickness Insurance Program.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 9</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">MISSING, INTERNMENT, PRISONER OF WAR - BENEFITS</P>
<B><P>A. </B>Captains, First Officers and Second Officers who while engaged in the MAC</P>
<P>Operation are interned or taken prisoner of war by a foreign government shall </P>
<P>receive compensation at the salary specified in the Basic Agreement for the </P>
<P>periods during which they are interned or held prisoner of war; provided, </P>
<P>however, that in the absence of knowledge on the part of the Company as to </P>
<P>whether a pilot is alive or dead, compensation in such amounts will be allowed </P>
<P>for a period of twelve (12) months after such Captain, First Officer or Second </P>
<P>Officer was last known to the Company to have been interned or held prisoner of </P>
<P>war.</P>
<P>When after such twelve (12) month period it has still not been established </P>
<P>whether such pilots are alive or dead, Captains, First Officers and Second </P>
<P>Officers shall be allowed compensation at the salary specified in the Basic </P>
<P>Agreement from and after such twelve (12) month period until death is </P>
<P>established or until there is a sufficient presumption of death to permit payment </P>
<P>of the death benefit provided in Section 7 of this Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<P>In the event such Captain, First Officer or Second Officer is later found to be </P>
<P>alive, he shall receive retroactively the difference in pay between the total </P>
<P>compensation (including death benefit) paid by the Company under this Section </P>
<P>and the monthly amounts which would have been paid under Paragraph A of this </P>
<P>Section and such monthly pay shall then be resumed for the duration of </P>
<P>internment or imprisonment.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>Captains, First Officers and Second Officers who while engaged in the MAC</P>
<P>Operation become missing and whose whereabouts become unknown shall be</P>
<P>allowed compensation at the salary specified in the Basic Agreement for a period </P>
<P>of twelve (12) months after disappearance or until such date as death is </P>
<P>established, whichever first occurs. If upon the expiration of the twelve (12) </P>
<P>month period any such Captain, First Officer or Second Officer is still missing and </P>
<P>his whereabouts are unknown, or if prior to that time his death is established, the </P>
<B><P>Page 140</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Company shall pay the death benefit provided for in Section 7 of this </P>
<P>Supplemental Agreement.</P>
<P>The monthly compensation allowable under this Section to pilots interned, </P>
<P>held prisoner of war or missing shall be credited to such pilot on the books of the </P>
<P>Company and shall be disbursed by the Company in accordance with written </P>
<P>directions from such pilots.</P>
<B><P>F. </B>Any payments due to any pilot under this Section which are not covered by a</P>
<P>written direction as above required shall be held by the Company for such pilot </P>
<P>and in the event of his death shall be paid to the legal representative of his </P>
<P>estate.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>The monthly compensation allowable under this Section shall be in lieu of all</P>
<P>compensation provided for by any law in respect to persons interned, held </P>
<P>prisoner of war or missing and shall also be in lieu of all salary, expenses and </P>
<P>subsistence during the period in which a pilot is interned, held prisoner of war or </P>
<P>missing.</P>
<B><P>H. </B>Pilots shall maintain and continue to accrue seniority and longevity for pay</P>
<P>purposes during periods in which they are interned, held prisoner of war or </P>
<P>missing.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 10</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">GENERAL CONDITIONS</P>
<P>The provisions for death benefits in Section 7 and for disability benefits in </P>
<P>Section 8 are intended to apply to Captains, First Officers and Second Officers </P>
<P>while assigned to the MAC Operation, as follows:</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-1- </B>When outside the continental United States, in connection with or as a </P>
<P>result of said operations irrespective of whether they are actually engaged in </P>
<P>active duty at the time of death or injury.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;A-2- </B>When within the continental United States, only if they are actually </P>
<P>engaged in the course of employment at the time of death or injury, except that when not actually engaged in the course of employment at the time of death or </P>
<P>injury, Captains, First Officers and Second Officers shall receive the group </P>
<P>insurance benefits normally in effect under the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 141</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>The obligation of the Company to make any payment is subject to the </P>
<P>condition that the injury or disease resulting in the permanent total or partial </P>
<P>disability shall not have been occasioned solely by his attempted suicide.</P>
<B><P ALIGN="CENTER">SECTION 11</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS</P>
<P>All provisions of the 1985 Pilot Agreement not specifically amended or </P>
<P>excepted by this Supplemental Agreement shall remain in full force and effect </P>
<P>and applicable to the Company's MAC Operation.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>In the event the MAC Operation requires passports and inoculations for pilots, </P>
<P>any actual necessary expenses shall be borne by the Company. Inoculations will </P>
<P>be given at Company designated places.</P>
<B><P>C. </B>Pilots will continue to fly any MAC flight deemed necessary to the national </P>
<P>defense provided such flights are solely military in nature and carry cargo </P>
<P>composed entirely of military requirements even if at the time such military flights </P>
<P>are necessary the pilots have withdrawn their airline service.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C-1- </B>To assure the movement of a particular flight under such circumstances, </P>
<P>the Association will require certification by an appropriate Company official </P>
<P>designated by the Company that such flight is in accordance with specifications </P>
<P>set forth above. This certification shall be provided prior to movement of the flight </P>
<P>where feasible or, where not feasible, promptly thereafter.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;C-2- </B>Pilots who fly such military traffic will not lose any benefits accruing to </P>
<P>other pilots which they would otherwise have received upon settlement of an </P>
<P>unresolved labor dispute.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>No pilot shall be required to move to the location of a critical MAC assignment,</P>
<P>unless required by the government. Moving expenses will not be authorized until</P>
<P>ninety (90) days after the date of the MAC vacancy. All moving shall be in </P>
<P>accordance with Section 10 of the Basic Agreement.</P>
<B><P>E. </B>This MAC Supplemental Agreement shall become effective June 15, 1985 and </P>
<P>shall run concurrently with the 1985 Pilot Agreement.</P>
<P>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have signed this Supplemental Agreement </P>
<P>this 9th day of May, 1991.</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>&nbsp;</P>
