&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 97</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<I><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Month End Absence Rule</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Hal Stepinsky</P>
<P>Contract Administrator</P>
<P>UAL/MEC</P>
<P>Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court - Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, Illinois 60018</P>
<P>Dear Hal,</P>
<P>Attached is a document that the parties have agreed accurately explains the</P>
<P>November 22, 1994 Letter of Agreement regarding the "Month-End Absence</P>
<P>Rule."</P>
<P>In accordance with our mutual commitment to give wide distribution to</P>
<P>this information, it will be included with the Letters of Agreement to be published</P>
<P>as an addendum to the current Collective Bargaining Agreement booklet.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ G. L. Andrews</P>
</U><P>Gerald L. Andrews</P>
<P>Director of</P>
<P>Flight Contract Administration</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Month-End Absence Rule</P>
</B><P>Since the 1981 Agreement, the Company has had the right to unilaterally adjust</P>
<P>pilot schedules in order to make them legal from month to month. Once this</P>
<P>month end adjustment is made, any absence over the month end that develops</P>
<P>thereafter is paid on the basis of the adjusted, legal schedules, as they occur in</P>
<P>both months. Shortly after this provision became effective with the 1981</P>
<P>Agreement, ALPA and the Company agreed to an interpretation of this provision</P>
<P>Intended to deal with concerns both parties had about schedule repairs that</P>
<P>might be made under the new provision when the affected pilot was planned to</P>
<P>be absent (vacation, training, etc.) at the beginning of a month. In order to avoid</P>
<P>having changes occur to an absent pilot's schedule that he couldn't control and</P>
<P>might not even have an opportunity to know about (e.g.; in the case of long term</P>
<P>sick leave), it was decided that for most planned absences in a pilot's schedule</P>
<P>that spanned a month-end or began on the first of a month, the pay for both the</P>
<P>old month (month "A") and new month (month "B") would be based entirely</P>
<B><P>Page 98 Letter 94-12</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>on what the pilot's published schedule included in these two months, as</P>
<P>awarded, without giving any consideration to the usual effect of month-end</P>
<P>carry overs or conflicts - if and when any conflicts existed. This means that the</P>
<P>pay forany carry-over trip from month "A" to month "B" is cut off at midnight at</P>
<P>month end;<B> </B>however, all trips at the beginning of month "B" are paid, even if the carry-over trip normally would have been in conflict.</P>
<P>The basic rule is: If, at the time the Company reconciles month-end schedule </P>
<P>conflicts created by carryover trips from the current month (month "A"), a pilot</P>
<P>has a known absence either over the upcoming month end or beginning on the</P>
<P>first day of the following month (month "B', then the Company will not repair that</P>
<P>pilot's month end schedule conflict, if one exists. In this case, the pilot's pay for</P>
<P>both months will be based on the pay value of the trips or portions of trips which</P>
<P>appear in his awarded schedules as published for both months. All that is</P>
<P>necessary for this rule to apply is for there to be a qualifying absence when</P>
<P>month-end conflicts are being worked on; when there is, this process always will</P>
<P>be followed and the pay will be split at midnight</P>
<P>at month end, whether or not the two months' schedules would have been in</P>
<P>conflict. Some special cases:</P>
<P>a. This above general rule also applies when the absence in month "B" does not</P>
<P>begin on the very first day of the month, provided the carry-over trip from month "A" projects into the absence.</P>
<P>b. It is possible, though rare, for a very long trip at the end of month "A" to satisfy</P>
<P>the circumstances described in "a", above, and also to entirely transcend a</P>
<P>shorter trip at the beginning of month "B" that does not touch the absence. (E.g.,</P>
<P>an 8 day trip beginning on the 31st of month "A", a 4 day trip beginning on the</P>
<P>1st of month "B" and a vacation beginning on the 6th of month "B".) In this case,</P>
<P>this month-end pay rule continues to apply, however the pilot would be legal, in</P>
<P>position and expected to fly the 4 day trip on the 1st.</P>
<P>c. Another variation on "a.", above that bears mentioning is created when the</P>
<P>carryover trip from month "A" does not project into the absence, but the carryover</P>
<P>trip conflicts with a trip at the beginning of month "B" that does project into the</P>
<P>absence. (E.g., a 3 day trip beginning on the 31st of month "A", a 4 day trip</P>
<P>beginning on the 2nd of month "B" and a vacation beginning on the 5th of month</P>
<P>"B".) This is not really a special case; since, in this situation, there is no</P>
<P>application of this month-end absence rule because neither of the required</P>
<P>conditions is met: There is no absence beginning on the first of month "B" nor</P>
<P>does the carry-over trip project into the vacation period. In this case, the</P>
<P>carryover trip and the first trip in the pilots line for month "B" require regular</P>
<P>month-end repair since the pilot will fly the carryover trip and cannot also get</P>
<B><P>Letter 94-17&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 99</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>paid for the conflicting trip in month "B"- even though he would not have flown the</P>
<P>trip in month "B" because it projects into the absence.</P>
<P>d. In the event a pilot is on sick leave at the beginning of an outbound trip at the</P>
<P>end of month "A" that qualified him for the application of this "month-end absence</P>
<P>rule" due to having a vacation beginning early in month "B" the pay for the</P>
<P>outbound portion of any carryover trip that appears in month "A" that projects into</P>
<P>the vacation shall be paid as vacation instead of sick leave.</P>
<P>e. This "month-end absence" rule will not be applied to pilots whose planned</P>
<P>absences are due to an ALPA drop (such as attendance at a System Schedule</P>
<P>Committee meeting) or to a Company business drop (such as a special</P>
<P>assignment). For those two types of planned absences only, month-end conflict</P>
<P>resolution will take place as if the pilot were expected to perform the month-end</P>
<P>flying.</P>
<P>3. The Association will co-sponsor the distribution of the above rules, acknowledging ALPA's agreement with this month-end application and, thereafter, both ALPA and the Company will continue to publicize these rules so that pilots with month-end
absences</P>
<P>will have accurate information about how to preference schedules when they have such absences. The Company will include a reminder with each month's schedule preferencing package to alert pilots to these special month end absence rules.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 100 Letter 94-12</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EXAMPLES</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;"Month-End Absence Rule"</P>
</B><P>The following illustrations are intended to provide additional examples of the</P>
<P>situations cited in the attached Settlement Letter. The first two examples below</P>
<P>illustrate the "normal" application of the "Month-End Absence Rule". Thereafter, the small letters "a" through "e", correspond to the letters which identify each "special case" situation. For some of these situations, more than one example is
provided, as noted. (For further reference, all examples in this document are numbered consecutively.)</P>
<B><P>Example #1 (Normal application)</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>28</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>29</FONT></TD>

<P>30</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">

<P>5</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">

<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 7</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>8</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">

<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</P>
<P>ID Y</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">

<P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>ID Y</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&lt;------------vacation----------------------------------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>In the above case, the pilot is paid for the value of ID "X' only for the 30th and 31st of Month "A" (not for the carry-over value in Month "B") and for all of ID on the 1st, 2<SUP>nd</SUP> and 3rd of Month "B".</P>

<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;---------------VACATION----------------------------------- </FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Even though the above pilot could have legally flown all of ID "X" on the 30th, 31st, 1st and 2nd (were he not on vacation), the pay works the same as in Example 1; i.e., the "Month-End Absence rule still applies. Specifically, the
pilot is paid for the value of ID "X" only for the 30th and 31st of Month "At, (not the carry-over value) and for all of ID "Y" on the 4th, 5th and 6th of Month "B".</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 94-12&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 101</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Example #3 (Special Case "a".)</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>

<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&lt;------------vacation------------------------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Here, again, the "Month-End Absence Rule" applies because the carry-over pairing projects into the absence, even though the absence does not begin on the 1st of Month "B".</P>
<B><P>Example #4 (Variation on Special Case "a.")</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>28</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>29</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>30</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>31</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>1</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>2</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>3</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>4</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>5</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>6</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; 7</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>8</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>ID X</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>ID Y</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&lt;--------vacation-----------------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>In the above case, the "Month-End Absence Rule" does not apply because the carry-over trip does not protect into the absence. The pilot would fly and be paid for ID "X" since it does not project into his vacation. ID "Y" would be
dropped because of a normal month-end conflict with ID "X'. (ID "Y" would not be paid as overlap because, even in a vacation, a pilot cannot be paid for a trip that his schedule shows he wouldn't have been legal to fly.)</P>
<B><P>Example #5 (Special Case "b.")</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>

<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&lt;-------vacation---------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Letter 94-12&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 102</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>In the above case, the carryover trip projects into the vacation, which makes it subject to the "Month-End Absence Rule"; that is, ID "X" is paid only for the 30th and 31st of Month "A". Also, in this case, the pilot is legal and in
position to fly ID "Y" on the 1st of Month "B"</P>
<B><P>Example #6 (Special Case "b.")</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&lt;---------vacation----------------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>The difference between Example #6 and Example #5 is that, in Example #6, both ID "X" and ID "Y" project into the vacation. In this situation, the "Month-End Absence Rule" applies to I D "X' so that it is paid only for the 30th and
31st of Month "A", however ID "Y" is dropped for vacation overlap and is paid as vacation.</P>
<B><P>Example #7 (Special Case "c.")</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=585>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=14>
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=584>
<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>

<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>

<TD WIDTH="6%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=44>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>8</FONT></TD>

</TR>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=584>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&lt;------vacation-------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>In the above case, there is no application of-the "Month-End Absence Rule" because</P>
<P>there is no month-end absence nor is there a carry-over trip that protects into an</P>
<P>absence. In this situation, a regular month-end conflict exists and is subject to normal</P>
<P>repair. The pilot would fly ID "X" and drop ID "Y" due: to the conflict.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 103&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 94-18</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=588>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Example #8 (Special Case "d.")</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>28</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>29</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>30</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>31</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>1</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>2</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>3</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;4</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>5</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;6</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;7</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>8</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>ID X</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</P>
<P>ID Y</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</P>
<P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&gt;&gt;&gt;&gt;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">
<P>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long Term Sick Leave---- --</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial">&gt;&lt;-------------------vacation-----------------------------------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>The above is another variation on Example #1, showing the effect of two "end-to-end", absences. There is no difference from Example #1 in the amount of pay. here is, however, a difference in accounting, since in this case the
pilot's pay for ID "X" on the 30th and 31st of Month "A" is paid as vacation time and is not charged as sick leave. This is an example of the only new application, which is being implemented as a result of this settlement.</P>
<B><P>Example #9 (Special Case "e.")</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">Month "A"-------------&gt;&lt;---------------Month "B" -----------------</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>


<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=1 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP" HEIGHT=47>

<TR><TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" VALIGN="TOP">

<TD WIDTH="8%" VALIGN="TOP">
<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>ID X</FONT></TD>

</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P></FONT>
<TABLE BORDER CELLSPACING=2 CELLPADDING=7 WIDTH=590>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><FONT FACE="Arial">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&lt;SSC Meeting-------&gt;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>In the above situation, although there is a month-end absence, this is one of the</P>
<P>exceptions to which wPPe have agreed the "Month-End Absence Rule" does not apply. In this case, the lines would be repaired just as if the pilot were expected to fly all trips in both months.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 94-18</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=588>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<I><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Contribut ions to DAP</P>
</I><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LETTER OF AGREEMENT</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;between</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THE AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;in the service of</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;as represented by</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THE AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION, INTERNATIONAL</P>
<P>THIS LETTER OF AGREEMENT is made and entered into in accordance with</P>
<P>the provisions of Title II of the Railway Labor Act, as amended, by and between</P>
<P>UNITED AIR LINES, INC. (hereinafter referred to as the "Company") and the</P>
<P>AIR LINE PILOTS in the service of UNITED AIR LINES, INC., as represented by</P>
<P>the AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION, INTERNATIONAL (hereinafter referred to</P>
<P>as the "Association")</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;WITNESSETH:</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the Internal Revenue Code places limits on the amounts which may</P>
<P>be contributed annually to the qualified defined contribution plans maintained by</P>
<P>the Company on behalf of the pilots; and WHEREAS, these limits apply to the</P>
<P>sum of the Company's contributions to the UAL Corporation Employee Stock</P>
<P>Ownership Plan (hereinafter referred to as the "ESOP"), the Company's</P>
<P>contributions to the United Air Lines, Inc. Pilots' Directed Account Retirement</P>
<P>Income Plan (hereinafter referred to as the "DAP"), and the pilots' pre-tax</P>
<P>and after-tax contributions to the DAP; and</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the Company's consultants have advised the Company that, due to</P>
<P>these limits, in 1995 it is likely that most pilots will be allowed to make pre-tax</P>
<P>contributions up to the federal limit of $9,240); and</P>
<P>WHEREAS, after the additional ESOP tranche purchase to be made in July of</P>
<P>each year during the Wage Investment Period, the Company's consultants will</P>
<P>be able to make a more precise projection of the pilots/ability to make pre-tax</P>
<P>and aftertax contributions during that year; and</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the Company and the Association wish to state the agreement they</P>
<P>have reached regarding the ability of pilots to make pre- tax and after-tax</P>
<P>contributions to the DAP during the Wage Investment Period of the ESOP;</P>
<B><P>Letter 94-18</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=588>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>NOW, THEREFORE, it is mutually agreed as follows:</P>
<B><P>1.</B> The ability of participants in the DAP to make after-tax contributions to the</P>
</FONT><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>DAP during 1995 is suspended effective January 1, 1995. (The ability of</P>
</B></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>participants in the DAP to make pre-tax contributions to the DAP during 1995</P>
<P>is not affected as of January 1, 1995, but will be reviewed, as provided in</P>
<P>paragraph 2 below, in August 1995.)</P>
<B><P>2. </B>After the ESOP tranche purchase occurring in July 1995, the Company will</P>
<P>obtain the advice of its consultants regarding the DAP participants' ability to</P>
<P>make both pre-tax and after-tax contributions to the DAP during 1995, up to the</P>
<P>limits permitted under the Internal Revenue Code. The Company will provide the</P>
<P>Association with a report covering the advice received from its consultants. The</P>
<P>Company and the Association will meet during August 1995 to determine jointly,</P>
<P>based on the consultants' advice; (a) whether or not to revoke the suspension of</P>
<P>after-tax contributions effective January 1, 1995 in whole or in part, for the</P>
<P>remainder of 1995, with respect to some or all of the participants in the DAP;</P>
<P>and (b) whether or not to refund, in whole or in part, pre-tax contributions already</P>
<P>made in 1995, and earnings thereon as required by law; and (c) whether to</P>
<P>suspend pre-tax contributions in whole or in part for the remainder of 1995.</P>
<P>Based upon the consultants' advice, any such actions may apply to some or all</P>
<P>participants. If the Company and the Association are unable to make such a joint</P>
<P>determination, then the Company shall take such action consistent with the</P>
<P>terms of the DAP and applicable law as the Company determines in good faith is</P>
<P>necessary to maintain the tax-qualified status of the DAP and to avoid</P>
<P>penalties imposed upon the Company.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>By November of each year after 1994 during the Wage Investment Period, the</P>
<P>Company will obtain the advice of its consultants regarding the DAP participants'</P>
<P>ability to make both pre-tax and after-tax contributions to the DAP in the following</P>
<P>year, up to the limits permitted under the Internal Revenue Code. The Company will provide the Association with a report covering the advice received from its</P>
<P>consultants. The Company and the Association will meet during each such</P>
<P>November to determine jointly, based on the consultants' advice, whether or no</P>
<P>to impose a suspension of the DAP participants' ability to make pre-tax and/or</P>
<P>after-tax contributions to the DAP to be effective January 1 of the following year.</P>
<P>Based on the consultants/advice, any such suspension may be partial or total,</P>
<P>and may apply to some or all participants. If the Company and the Association</P>
<P>are unable to make such a joint determination, then the Company shall take</P>
<P>such action consistent with the terms of the DAP and applicable law as the</P>
<P>Company determines in good faith is necessary to maintain the tax-qualified</P>
<P>status of the DAP and to avoid penalties (including loss of tax deductions) which</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 94-18</P></B></FONT>
<TABLE CELLSPACING=0 BORDER=0 CELLPADDING=9 WIDTH=588>
<TR><TD VALIGN="TOP">
<P><B><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=5>&#9;</B></FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE>

<FONT FACE="Arial"><P>might otherwise be imposed upon the Company.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>After the ESOP tranche purchase occurring in July of each year during the</P>
<P>Wage Investment Period after 1995, the Company will obtain the advice of its</P>
<P>consultants regarding the contributions to the DAP during that year, up to the</P>
<P>limits permitted under the Internal Revenue Code. The Company will provide the</P>
<P>Association with a report covering the advice received from its consultants. The</P>
<P>Company and the Association will meet during August of each such year to</P>
<P>determine jointly, based on the consultants' advice; (a) whether or not to modify</P>
<P>or revoke their decision (of the.<B> </B>previous November) regarding the DAP</P>
<P>participants' ability to make pre-tax and/or after-tax contributions during that</P>
<P>year, and (b) whether or not to refund contributions already made during such</P>
<P>year, and earnings thereon, as required by law. Based on the consultants"</P>
<P>advice, any such modification or revocation may be partial or total, and may</P>
<P>apply to some or all participants. If the Company and the Association are unable</P>
<P>to make such a joint determination, then the Company shall take such action</P>
<P>consistent with the terms of the DAP and applicable law as the Company</P>
<P>etermines in good faith is necessary to maintain the tax- qualified status of the</P>
<P>DAP and to avoid penalties (including loss of tax deductions) which might</P>
<P>otherwise be imposed upon the Company.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>Unless otherwise explicitly modified in this Letter of Agreement, the agreement</P>
<P>between the Company and the Association regarding the pilots' ability to make</P>
<P>pretax and after-tax contributions to the DAP remains unchanged.</P>
<P>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have signed this Letter of Agreement this 15<SUP>th</SUP> day of December 1994.</P>
<P>WITNESS: &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FOR UNITED AIRLINES, INC.</P>
<U><P>/s/ G. L. Andrews</U>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;/s/ John R. Samolis</P>
<U><P>/s/ J. A. Craven</U>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;John R. Samolis</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Vice President</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Labor Relations</P>
<P>WITNESS:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FOR THE AIR LINE PILOTS IN THE</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SERVICE OF UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<U><P>/s/ J. Stephen Smith</P>

<U><P>/s /W. J. Arscott</U>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;J. Randolph Babbitt, President&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;/s/ Larry D. Schulte&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Air Line Pilots Association, International.</P>
<P>/s/ H. E. Stepinsky</P>

<I><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>ESOP Revisions</P>
</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><B><FONT FACE="Arial">UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;December 22, 1994</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Captain Harlow B. Osteboe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Captain Osteboe:</P>
<P>It is agreed that United will cause UAL Corporation to amend the ESOP and</P>
<P>Supplemental ESOP in accordance with our discussions, including the following</P>
<P>revisions:</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Notwithstanding the fact that ALPA does not represent student flight officers, those students will be included in the ALPA Employee Group under these plans.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Compensation included in a participants first and second regular January (or May, 2000) paychecks which relates to services performed in the prior year will be included in ESOP compensation for the prior year.</P>
<P>If the terms of this settlement are acceptable, please sign and date the original and return for our files.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ John R. Samolis</P>
</U><P>John R. Samolis</P>
<P>Vice President</P>
<P>Labor Relations</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>23rd day of December, 1994.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<U><P>/s/ Harlow B. Osteboe</P>
</U><P>Captain Harlow B. Osteboe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 107&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-10</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-10</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>75 Hour FAR</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED
AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Harlow Osteboe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Harlow,</P>
<P>The parties have mutually agreed to the following provisions as an addition to Section 20-E of the Agreement in order to accommodate the effect of the new FAR that imposes new limitations on crew composition involving Captains and First Officers who
have less than seventy-five (75) flight hours of PIC or SIC time in that equipment type after completing transition training. The fallowing provisions apply only to Captains and First Officers who are not "initial" Captains and First Officers; the
provisions of Section 20-E continue to apply to "operating experience" for initial Captains and First Officers.</P>
<P>Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 6-A-2 and Section 20-B-1-f, Captains and First Officers shall be subject to the following schedule and reserve assignment provisions if, at the time the line or trip assignment is made, the Captain or First
Officer has not yet performed seventy-five (75) hours of flying as Pilot in Command or as Second in Command in his current aircraft type.</P>
<B><P>1.</P>
<P>1-a- </B>If a Captain is senior enough to be awarded a primary line of flying through</P>
<P>preferencing upon his activation into his new Captain assignment, and if he does</P>
<P>preference and is awarded such a line, that line shall become his "OE" line.</P>
<B><P>1-b- </B>If a First Officer is senior enough to be awarded a primary line of flying</P>
<P>through preferencing upon his activation into a new First Officer assignment, and if he does preference and is awarded such a line, that line shall become his "OE" line providing that the Captain holding the same line has completed seventy-five (75)
hours as PIC or SIC in that equipment type at the time the monthly schedule assignment is being made. In the event the First Officers preference would normally result in his being awarded a line with a Captain who has not fulfilled the above seventy five
(75) hour requirement, the First Officer will be awarded the next available line, according to his preference, to which the assigned Captain has satisfied the seventy five (75) hour requirement.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Lineholder Captains and First Officers who have not accumulated seventy-five (75) hours in their current assignment shall not be eligible to trip trade into an assignment which dines not comply with the above requirement, nor into an
assignment in which the other pilot position is "open".</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-10 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 108</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>3. </B>If the newly transitioned Captain or First Officer does not have sufficient seniority to be awarded a line of flying under "1.", above, the Captain or First Officer will be awarded the reserve line to which his seniority entitles him.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>Newly transitioned Captains and First Officers who have not accumulated seventy-five (75) hours as PIC or SIC in their current type at the time the assignment is made will not be eligible to be awarded secondary lines.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>A newly transitioned Captain or First Officer who is a reserve and who has not</P>
<P>accumulated seventy-five (75) hours in his current equipment type may be bypassed in the FIFO assignment rotation in order to be assigned flying which does not violate the seventy-five (75) hour requirement. Further, such Captain or First Officer may,
at his request, be placed at the top of the FIFO list until he has acquired seventy-five (75) hours in his current assignment. Each pilot who requests to be placed at the top of the list will be placed just below all other pilots who previously requested
such placement.</P>
<B><P>6. </B>Newly transitioned Captains and First Officers who have not accumulated seventy-five (75) hours in their current equipment type and who do not have a line or reserve assignment for the current month at the time they complete JOE, may be
assigned to reserve or to an existing partial line or to a partial line created for them from open flying that does not violate the seventy-five (75) hour requirement. All trip pairings assigned to pilots who have not completed the seventy-five (75) hour
requirement must, at the time of assignment, fall into one of the following groups: (1) a complete DSL published sequence, (2) a portion of a single published sequence or (3) any sequence to which a complete crew is assigned as a unit.</P>
<P>If this accurately reflects our understanding, please sign and return 2 copies our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<P>/s/ John R. Samolis</P>
<P>John R. Samolis</P>
<P>Vice President</P>
<P>Labor Relations</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>24th day of July, 1995.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<U><P>/s/ Harlow B. Osteboe</P>
</U><P>Harlow Osteboe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 109 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-1</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-1</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Schedule Flexibility</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Chairman</P>
<P>Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Mike,</P>
<P>As a result of the recommendations that were compiled by the Dependability Task Team, the parties have agreed to consider modifying the Agreement to allow pilots to have greater control over their schedules. Since most of the following modifications
require considerable computer support in order to be administered reliably and some of the concepts are untried and intended to be experimental, this Letter of Agreement constitutes a mutual commitment to pursue development of the necessary processes and
computer support in order to initiate trials of the concepts listed below and then to implement each provision when the panics agree that appropriate computer support is in place. Once implemented, any or all of these provisions can be discontinued by
notice being given to the other party at least 90 days prior to the month in which the provision is to be discontinued.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>1. Unlimited Trip Trading with Open Flying</P>
</B><P>Automated trip trading with open flying will include the following concepts:</P>
<B><P>1-a- </B>The automated open flying trip trade system will use (1) a single monthly "run down", prior to the beginning of the subject month, during which trades will be awarded based on relative seniority and (2) an ongoing "first come, first
served" system; both similar to the current Shuttle system.</P>
<B><P>1-b- </B>No pilot will be permitted to drop a trip if it reduces the projected value of his line below fifty (50) credit hours, without Company concurrence.</P>
<B><P>1-c- </B>Rules for establishing blackout and embargo days will be published and</P>
<P>available to pilots. It is intended that these two identifiers will be applied and</P>
<P>removed on a dynamic basis as coverage circumstances change; as such, it is</P>
<P>important that each pilot be aware of the factors that may cause his trading/</P>
<P>dropping opportunities to change as time passes.</P>
<B><P>1-d- </B>New mutually agreed upon rules will be established and published to clearly define the opportunities regarding a trade that touches an embargo day or that departs on a blackout day. These rules will provide greater access than provided by
the current Trip Trade Letter (93-2).</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 110</P>
<P>1-e- </B>Depending upon the size of the domicile, up to 3% of the credit time in any</P>
<P>equipment, status and domicile may be left as open time to facilitate trip trading</P>
<P>with open flying.</P>
<B><P>1-f- </B>A pilot will be permitted to trip trade with or pick up open flying which results</P>
<P>in his projection exceeding the applicable actual flight time limit by up to two (2)</P>
<P>hours, if the trade involves flying on a blackout or embargo day. Once a pilot</P>
<P>becomes projected above the normal monthly flight time limit as a result of this</P>
<P>provision, he will not be required to drop a trip or portion of a trip if he later</P>
<P>becomes further over projected for any reason, unless he becomes projected more than one hour above the projection he had just prior to the assignment that</P>
<P>produced the additional hour.</P>
<B><P>1-g- </B>A pilot may trip trade with another pilot as long as the resulting trade is legal under the provisions of Section 5.</P>
<B><P>2. Overprojection Protection</P>
</B><P>The provisions of Section 5-B-2-a, 5-B-3 and the related provisions of the</P>
<P>International Supplement shall be modified as follows:</P>
<B><P>2-a- </B>If a pilot initially becomes projected over the actual limit applicable to him under Section 5-B-2-a (and related provisions of the International Supplement) and such overprojection is entirely (1) the result of flying a carryover trip
from the prior month or (2) the result of his flying trips that did not project him to exceed the applicable limit at the time the assignment was made (including trips assigned under the provisions of Section Section 20-H or 20-I); then such pilot may, at
his discretion, fly the remainder of his schedule without being required to drop any flying in order to comply with the 5-B-2-a limits.</P>
<B><P>2-b- </B>A pilot may indicate his willingness to fly his complete schedule under this provision even if his projection should exceed the allowable actual monthly flight time due to month-end carry overs or operational increases in flight time. A
mainline pilot may make this election at any time including during the line award process, in which case any adjustment made necessary by an inbound carry-over conflict can be repaired up to 83 actual flight hours (85 actual hours for international
lines). A pilot may contact OPBCM via phone or computer during the operating month to rescind his willingness to further exceed his actual projection. The Company will then be required to make the appropriate adjustment to prevent the pilot's actual
projection from exceeding by more than one hour his actual projection at the time he contacted OPBCM.</P>
<B><P>2-c- </B>If a pilot initially acquired a high flight time projection under the provisions of "2-a." above, he shall not be required to drop a trip due to funkier overprojection, except under the conditions described in "1-f", above,</P>
<B><P>3. Make Up of Sick Leave</P>
</B><P>The provisions of Section 7-D of the International Supplement (voluntary makeup of sick leave) shall apply to all pilots, including Shuttle pilots as follows:.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 111 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-1</P>
<P>3-a- </B>Such pilot shall be eligible to restore all or part of his accrued sick leave used for the illness absence on an actual hour for actual hour basis.</P>
<B><P>3-b- </B>Restoration of sick leave accrual shall be accomplished by picking up open time under the provisions of Section 20-H-5 of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>3-c- </B>Pick up under this provision shall be limited to the month in which the</P>
<P>absence occurs.</P>
<B><P>4. Language Conflicts</P>
</B><P>It is understood that, should there be language within the Agreement that appeal to be in conflict with the provisions of this Letter, this Letter shall prevail. If this accurately reflects our understanding, please sign and return 2 copies for
our files.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ John R. Samolis</P>
</U><P>John R. Samolis</P>
<P>Vice President Labor</P>
<P>Relations</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>12th day of February, 1996.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-ALPA Master Executive Council</P>

<P>Revised as of this 26th day of October, 2000.</P>
<U><P>/s/ William P. Hobgood</P>
</U><P>William P. Hobgood</P>
<P>Senior Vice President</P>
<P>People</P>
<U><P>/s/ F.C. Dubinsky</P>
</U><P>Captain F.C. Dubinsky</P>
<P>Chairman</P>
<P>UAL/ALPA Master Executive Council.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 96-10 Page &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;112</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>96-10</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>International Training</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018-7180</P>
<P>Dear Michael,</P>
<P>As a result of the new requirement that some newly trained Captains on equipment that performs international flying be assigned only domestic flying before receiving additional international training, the parties have agreed to the following:</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Any pilot who is awaiting international training and/or who requires domestic flying due to the application of the "International Training Matrix" will be paid the value of his awarded line or the value of the flying he actually performs,
whichever is greater.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>In those domiciles where both international and domestic flying are available, a</P>
<P>pilot awaiting international training who is awarded a line with international flying in the line will be removed from those international trips and be available to be assigned to domestic flying on the days he was originally scheduled to fly. He will
be considered to be at the top of the FIFO list for this provision.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>In those domiciles where no or insufficient domestic flying is scheduled, a pilot</P>
<P>requiring domestic flying may, at his option, choose to be sent TDY, if TDY is</P>
<P>available at a domestic domicile. Such TDY assignments will be made in seniority order from those pilots who volunteer for TDY. Otherwise, these pilots will be eligible to be assigned individual domestic trip pairing originating from domestic
domiciles. Such assignments will be constructed by incorporating legal deadhead segments at the start and end of the pairings; however, these pairings are not subject to the provisions of Section 8-L-6. Pilots eligible for single trip domestic assignments
will be considered to be at the top of the FIFO list for this purpose.</P>
<P>If this accurately reflects our understanding, please sign and return 2 copies for our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ John R. Samolis</P>
</U><P>John R. Samolis</P>
<P>Vice President</P>
<P>Labor Relations</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>31st day of July, 1996.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 113 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 96-10</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 97-4 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 114</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>97-4</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Allocation of Flying Protocol</P>
</I><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UAL-ALPA</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;AGREEMENT ON A PROTOCOL</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;FOR A CONSULTATIVE PROCESS</P>
<P>FOR ALLOCATION OF FLYING ISSUES</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;BACKGROUND</P>
</B><P>The 1963 Pilot Agreement was the first to contain the provision which subsequently caused more System Board disputes between the Company and ALPA than any other provision of the contract. The provision appears in Section 20, titled allocation,
assignment and scheduling of flying, and reads:</P>
<P>It is the intent of the parties to this Agreement that this System Scheduling</P>
<P>Committee shall provide pilots with the opportunity to consult with and make</P>
<P>recommendations to the Company on the allocation of flying, assignment and</P>
<P>reduction of flying to pilot domiciles in accordance with the "equipment to seniority" concept:</P>
<P>"Equipment to seniority" shall mean that within the limits of flying hours available to a domicile by equipment type, the more senior pilots shall be given the opportunity to fly equipment in the following order:...</P>
<P>The System Board heard grievances submitted by ALPA alleging the Company was not complying with these provisions in 1967, 1970, 1971, 1973, 1984 and 1993. Each System Board decision, in addition to determining the contractual rights of the parties,
stands for the proposition that the Company and ALPA have had significant difficulty determining how to effectively implement ALPA's opportunity to consult with and make recommendations to the Company on the allocation of flying, assignment and reduction
of flying to pilot domiciles in accordance with the equipment to seniority concept.</P>
<P>Each System Board decision permitted the Company to make the final decision on allocation of flying issues. In these disputes, ALPA consistently maintained the Company failed to provide a meaningful opportunity to consult or that the Company failed to
comply with the equipment to seniority concept. In making decisions on allocating, assigning and scheduling of flying, the Company maintained that it could modify a literal application of seniority due to various factors, such as:</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>HUMAN/CONTRACTUAL FACTORS</P>
<P>- </B>Relative seniority of the equipment domicile</P>
<B><P>- </B>Current equipment domicile size</P>
<B><P>- </B>Other equipment types at the domicile</P>
<B><P>- </B>Number of pilots with future bids</P>
<B><P>- </B>Domicile stability.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 115 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 97-4</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>- </B>Impact of additional commuters</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ECONOMIC FACTORS</P>
<P>- </B>Best flown flight time credit</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTC with and w/o domicile</P>
<B><P>- </B>Impact on other domiciles</P>
<B><P>- </B>Efficient line construction</P>
<B><P>- </B>Varied ID's EOM conflicts</P>
<B><P>- </B>Stability</P>
<B><P>- </B>Future of equipment type</P>
<B><P>- </B>Training impact - retaining vs. closing base</P>
<B><P>- </B>Adequate reserve utilization</P>
<B><P>- </B>Administrative costs</P>
<P>Pursuant to the ESOP established in 1994, the parties adopted a Statement of</P>
<P>Principles which defined the basic ESOP expectations of the Company and ALPA. Two of those principles are:</P>
<B><P>It shall be our goal to encourage and embrace employee input into the decision making process in order to stimulate a feeling of personal &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;ownership.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
and</P>
<P>We will recognize and respect the managerial and representational roles &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and responsibilities of each organization.</P>
</B><P>The parties have noted that the allocation of flying provision of the contract and these two Statements of Principle are remarkably consistent with each other. The parties also recognize their recent experience with the DC10 equipment domicile
closing demonstrates continuing difficulties with implementing the provisions of Section 20-A-2</P>
<P>Therefore, the parties desire to establish a protocol which recognizes, respects and implements both the Contract and the Statement of Principles regarding this most vital element of the Company - Pilot relationship, that is, the allocation of flying,
assignment and reduction of flying in accordance with the equipment to seniority concept.</P>
<P>To that end, the Company must recognize its responsibility to give ALPA the</P>
<P>opportunity to provide meaningful input to the allocation and assignment of flying</P>
<P>process and ALPA must be confident that it has been given a legitimate opportunity to be consulted and to make recommendations before Company decisions are made on allocation of flying issues. The parties believe that ALPA's seat on the Board of
Directors, its Officers' regularly scheduled monthly meetings with the CEO and President, and the SSC's participation in the Company's strategic planning process significantly enhance this level of confidence. Accordingly, the following protocol,</P>
<B><P>Letter 97-4&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Page 116</P>
</B><P>which is intended to assist the Director of Flight Crew Resources and the System</P>
<P>Scheduling Committee, establishes the rights and obligations of each party whenever the Company must extend to ALPA the right to be consulted and to make recommendations on allocation and assignment of flying issues.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;PROTOCOL FOR CONSULTATIVE PROCESS</P>
<P>1. </B>The Parties agree that the following subject matters are within the concept of</P>
<P>allocation, assignment and scheduling of flying as described in Section 20 of the Pilot Agreement:</P>
<B><P>1-a- </B>opening new or closing existing domiciles,</P>
<B><P>1-b- </B>opening new equipment domiciles or closing equipment domiciles,</P>
<B><P>1-c- </B>changing the size of domiciles in accordance with standards to be agreed upon.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>When the need for a decision on an above referenced subject is identified, the Director of Flight Crew Resources (the Director) has the responsibility to give ALPA notice that it will be given the opportunity to be consulted and to make
recommendations prior to the time the Company makes its decision. The Director will give this notice by issuing to the System Scheduling Committee (SSC) a Notice of Proposed Decision Making (NPDM). The Director has a good faith responsibility to issue the
NPDM as soon as possible after the need arises to allow ALPA as much time as possible to respond.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>The NPDM shall contain:</P>
<B><P>3-a- </B>a statement of the issue the Company needs to decide,</P>
<B><P>3-b- </B>an estimate of the time frame within which the Company must make a</P>
<P>decision,</P>
<B><P>3-c- </B>specific information, if any, the Company may require from ALPA, and</P>
<B><P>3-d- </B>the date by which ALPA's recommendations are required to be submitted to the Director.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>The NPDM shall be delivered to the System Schedule Committee members by US Mail or by a more expeditious method, such as hand delivered or by FAX, except that it shall also be sent certified mail to the ALPA Master Chairman.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>The SSC will respond to the NPDM by certified mail as quickly as possible given the time frame within which a decision must be made. The response to the Director shall indicate the following:</P>
<B><P>5-a- </B>whether the SSC wishes to be consulted and given the opportunity to make a recommendation on the issue, and if it does, its initial impression about how and when it wants to address the issue, such as by conference call, at an immediate
meeting or at the next SSC meeting,</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 117 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 97-4</P>
<P>5-b- </B>any preliminary information it desires for its preparation and evaluation of the issue prior to discussions with the Company,</P>
<B><P>5-c- </B>an initial estimate of the time period the SSC believes will be required before it can make recommendations.</P>
<B><P>6. </B>The Director will provide all requested pertinent information in accordance with</P>
<P>Section 20-A-2-f of the Pilot Agreement. If the Director is unable to provide the</P>
<P>requested information, the Director will inform ALPA of the reasons therefore.</P>
<B><P>7. </B>When the parties discuss the issue, they will endeavor to identify the options</P>
<P>available to them at each stage of the decision making process and whether additional information or time is required to evaluate the options. The parties will consider, evaluate and apply the human, contractual and economic factors applicable to
allocation of flying issues as appropriate to each stage of the decision making process. When the SSC is satisfied that the parties have fully explored their reasonable options, the SSC will advise the Director when the SSC will be able to make its
recommendations to the Company. The SSC acknowledges that its recommendations must be submitted within the Company's time frame for decision.</P>
<B><P>8. </B>ALPA's internal protocol will identify the process by which the SSC will develop its recommendations before they are submitted to the Company.</P>
<B><P>9. </B>The SSC will submit its recommendation(s) in writing to the Director within the time limits specified in the NPDM, unless the parties have mutually agreed to a different deadline.</P>
<B><P>10. </B>If the SSC is unable to comply with the time limits, it may request additional time from the Director. The Director will advise the SSC whether additional time can be granted, and if not, the reasons therefore. If additional time cannot be
granted, the Director will advise the SSC when the decision will be made and when it will be announced.</P>
<B><P>11. </B>Before making his decision, the Director will consider and evaluate the</P>
<P>recommendations made by the SSC, if any, and will communicate in writing to the SSC the reasons for accepting or rejecting their recommendations.</P>
<B><P>12. </B>The SSC and the Director will provide feedback to each other on how well the</P>
<P>consultative process worked on each issue covered by a NPDM and the</P>
<P>improvements, if any, which they believe should be made to the process before the next NPDM is issued.</P>
<P>The parties agree this 24th day of February, 1997.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</FONT><U><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>/s/ Hart A. Langer</P>
</U></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>Hart A. Langer, Senior Vice President</P>
<P>Flight Operations, United Airlines.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</FONT><B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Letter 97-8&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Page 118</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>97-8</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>777 Crew Rest</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Michael,</P>
<P>All B-777 aircraft serving international destinations will be re-equipped with the</P>
<P>"Genesis" first class seat system. On all B-777 international flights of twelve (12)</P>
<P>hours scheduled flight time or less, one such seat will be reserved as a dedicated pilot rest facility. Until the "Genesis" seat installation process is completed, however, ALPA and Company negotiating committees have agreed to the following changes
in the B-777 crew rest policy.</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Seat 1E is the exclusive crew rest seat on all B-777 aircraft, and Seat 1F is to be assigned or occupied only if it is the last available seat in the first class cabin.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Both Seat 1E and Seat 1F shall be marked with appropriate seat coverings which identify the seats as reserved for crew rest. Additionally, a Customer Service Representative must advise the Captain of the status of Seat 1F at the time of
departure and hand the Captain the seat cover if it was necessary to assign Seat 1F.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>A Customer Service Representative will under no circumstances solicit the Captain or other crew members to relinquish Seat 1E.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>Provisions 1 through 3 above shall be incorporated into the Flight Attendant</P>
<P>Handbook and the Flight Operations Manual.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>A letter from John Edwardson which discusses provisions 1 through 3 above shall be sent to all Customer Service Representatives.</P>
<B><P>6. </B>The Company agrees it will discuss with the Association all future planned changes to the "Genesis" first class seating configuration prior to their implementation.</P>
<P>If this accurately reflects our understanding, please sign and return 2 copies for our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<P>/s/ Chuck Vanderheiden</P>
<P>Chuck Vanderheiden</P>
<P>Director - Labor Relations</P>
<P>Flight Employees</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 119 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 97-8</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>2nd day of May, 1997.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
<P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 97-9 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 120</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>97-9</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Open Flying for Flight Management</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018-7180</P>
<P>Dear Michael,</P>
<P>As a result of changes made to the open flying pick-up procedures for line pilots by the "trip-trade with open flying" Letter of Agreement, the parties have agreed to add the following companion changes to the pick up process for flight-qualified</P>
<P>management:</P>
<P>Flight qualified managers may use the "zero trade" provision of the trip trade with</P>
<P>open flying process to pick up open flying, with the following limitations:</P>
<P>The availability of trips which are eligible for pick up by a manager will be limited to those trips that have been placed into open flying as a result of a line pilot having already performed a trade with open flying; except that a manager may pick
up any trip that has been listed in open flying and available for pick up for at least 6 hours, or after 12 noon, local domicile time, whichever is later.</P>
<P>If this accurately reflects our understanding, please sign and return 2 copies for our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ Chuck Vanderheiden</P>
</U><P>Chuck Vanderheiden</P>
<P>Director - Labor Relations</P>
<P>Flight Employees</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>16th day of May, 1997.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
