<B><P>Page 121 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-13</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-13</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>FOQA Update</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</I><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;LETTER OF AGREEMENT</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;between</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;and</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THE AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;in the service of</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIR LINES</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;as represented by</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THE AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION,</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;INTERNATIONAL</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>THIS LETTER OF AGREEMENT is made and entered into in accordance with the provisions of Title 11 of the Railway Labor Act, as amended, by and between UNITED AIR LINES, INC. (hereinafter referred to as "the Company" or "United") and the AIR LINE PILOTS
in the service of UNITED AIRLINES, INC. as represented by the AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION, INTERNATIONAL (hereinafter referred to as "the Association" or "ALPA").</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;W I T N E S S E T H:</P>
<P>WHEREAS, it is the intent of the parties to implement a Flight Operations Quality</P>
<P>Assurance Program (FOQA) to analyze data for the sole purpose of enhancing safety and efficiency of flight operations,</P>
<P>WHEREAS, a Flight Operations Quality Assurance Program (FOQA) requires specific pilot protective provisions which are not currently included in the FAR's, and the Company and ALPA agree that the implementation of any Flight Operations Quality
Assurance Program (FOQA) will be held in abeyance until the required FAR protective provisions are effective or a waiver to United Air Lines is granted from the FM providing these protective provisions,</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the parties have successfully implemented a FOQA program per the</P>
<P>Letter of Agreement dated November 10, 1994,</P>
<P>WHEREAS, the Letter of Agreement was subsequently modified by an amendment.</P>
<P>Now, therefore, it is mutually agreed that this FOQA Letter of Agreement,</P>
<P>incorporating the changes per the Amendment, replace the FOQA Letter of Agreement dated November 10, 1994 contained within the 1994 Agreement between United Air Lines, Inc. and the Air Line Pilots in the service of United Air Lines, Inc. as
represented by the Air Line Pilots Association, International is amended as follows:</P>
<B><P>A. </B>DEFINITIONS:.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-13 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 122</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>A-1- </B>"FOQA Program" - A program designed to enhance flight safety through</P>
<P>controlled analysis of recorded flight date information.</P>
<B><P>A-2- </B>"Identifying Data" is any data or combination of data which allows collected data to be associated with a specific crew member.</P>
<B><P>A-3- </B>"Identified Data" is any collected data prior to removal of all identifying data.</P>
<B><P>A-4- </B>"Flight Data Recorder" is any device, equipment or system which collects, transmits or records in-flight data, whether installed to monitor pilot, aircraft component, or aircraft performance, or as consequence of performance of some other
function.</P>
<B><P>A-5- </B>"Cockpit voice recorder" is any device, equipment or system which monitors or records a pilot's voice while he or she is on an aircraft.</P>
<B><P>A-6- </B>"Information," is any data transmitted, recorded or collected by use of a flight data recorder, cockpit voice recorder or any other recording device. The term "Information" shall further include tapes, transcripts, reports, papers, memos,
statements, studies, charts, graphs or any other description, analysis or compilation of data collected by any such equipment.</P>
<B><P>A-7- </B>"FOQA Monitoring Team" - A committee of three management pilots</P>
<P>appointed by the company: one from Safety, one from Domicile Operation and one from the Flight Center and three ALPA pilots selected by the MEC.</P>
<B><P>A-8- </B>"Operational Excedence Event"- An event described by recorded data values indicating the aircraft was outside the normal operation envelope.</P>
<B><P>A-9- </B>"Operational Routine Event"- An event in routine operation of statistical</P>
<P>interest such as time into operation when flaps are retracted.</P>
<B><P>A-10- </B>"Designated Excedence Guidance Team Member" - a designated member of the ALPA Excedence Guidance Team who is conducting a specific event resolution and has the capability, if required, to identify the crew or crew members associated with
collected data. This ALPA Excedence Guidance Team member will be the only person capable of identifying the flight crew associated with this collected data.</P>
<B><P>A-11- </B>"ALPA Excedence Guidance Team" - MEC appointed pilots, designated to analyze operational events, and if necessary, identify, interview, exchange information with and provide guidance to the pilots involved. The Excedence Guidance Team
members are the only persons capable of identifying a crew associated with the event.</P>
<B><P>B. </B>FOQA PROGRAM:</P>
<B><P>B-1- </B>The design, implementation, and operation of a FOQA program shall be by mutual agreement between the Company and the Air Line Pilots' Association. Any variation from the agreed upon FOQA program shall require the mutual agreement of the
parties prior to implementation.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 123 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-13</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>B-2- </B>The FOQA Monitoring Team shall oversee the day to day operations of the FOQA Program and establish necessary policies and procedures to ensure compliance with the provisions of this agreement.</P>
<B><P>B-3- </B>The design of the FOQA program shall ensure the initial confidentiality and ultimate anonymity of individual crew members</P>
<B><P>B-4- </B>Flight data collected from any recording device installed on a Flight simulator will be an integral part of the FOQA program and be administered by the FOQA program personnel. This data will be considered FOQA data and comply with all the
provisions of the FOQA Agreement.</P>
<B><P>B-5- </B>The letter of Agreement dated 11/11/94, regarding aircraft data collection systems, is incorporated herein by reference.</P>
<B><P>B-6- </B>Any violation of the requirements of this agreed-upon FOQA program, or the terms herein, shall cause the FOQA program to be held in abeyance until the infraction is resolved to the mutual satisfaction of both parties.</P>
<B><P>C. </B>SCOPE:</P>
<B><P>C-1- </B>Sufficient de-identified data shall be maintained to fulfill the requirements of the agreed-upon FOQA program. All de-identified data, and analyses of such data, shall be made available to the parties.</P>
<B><P>C-2- </B>There shall be continual evaluation of excedence values by the parties.</P>
<B><P>C-3- </B>Any special studies or evaluations require mutual agreement by Company and Association members of the FOQA Monitoring Team.</P>
<B><P>C-4- </B>Government agencies may be given access to de-identified data on</P>
<P>Company property with approval of the FOQA Monitoring ream.</P>
<B><P>D. </B>DATA RETENTION:</P>
<B><P>D-1- </B>Identifying data shall be removed from identified data as soon as possible, but no later than seven (7) days from the date of acquisition of the data by the Company.</P>
<B><P>D-2- </B>Any employee/agent who has contact with any identified data used in a</P>
<P>FOQA program shall be prohibited from divulging any identifying data to any</P>
<P>individual other than an ALPA FOQA Monitoring Team member representative except as prescribed by statute or regulation.</P>
<B><P>E. </B>DATA USE:</P>
<B><P>E-1- </B>The sole contact with any flight crew member associated with a specific</P>
<P>excedence event shall be the "ALPA Excedence Guidance ream." (See diagram attached)</P>
<B><P>E-2- </B>Only the specific designated FOQA Excedence Guidance Team member shall be able to identify the individual crew members associated with any specific data. (See amended diagram attached).</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-13 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 124</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>E-3- </B>Any notes, memoranda, or other documents used by the designated "ALPA Excedence Guidance Team" in any contact with any flight crew member concerning a specific FOQA event shall be considered "identified data" for purposes of this agreement
and shall be "de-identified" in accordance with paragraph D-1 above.</P>
<B><P>E-4- </B>At a minimum, the FOQA program may be used for evaluation of the</P>
<P>following areas:</P>
<P>Aircraft performance</P>
<P>Aircraft system performance</P>
<P>Crew performance</P>
<P>Company procedures</P>
<P>Training programs</P>
<P>Training effectiveness</P>
<P>Aircraft design</P>
<P>ATC system</P>
<P>Airport issues</P>
<P>Meteorological issues</P>
<P>Any additional areas of evaluation which the parties may desire to include in the FOQA program must be mutually agreed upon by the Company and the</P>
<P>Association prior to implementation.</P>
<B><P>F. </B>DATA USE FOR TRAINING;</P>
<B><P>F-1- </B>Collected FOQA data may be used to enhance individual training when the Technological capabilities are available. The FOQA Monitoring Team must approve procedures and use of FOQA data for this purpose.</P>
<B><P>F-2- </B>Collected data may be used by an instructor, Standards Captain or Line</P>
<P>Check Airman to enhance the training.</P>
<B><P>F-3- </B>Collected data used for individualized training must be reviewed at the</P>
<P>completion of the training period, either simulator or aircraft, and destroyed after such review.</P>
<B><P>F-4- </B>Collected data cannot be used to evaluate the individual performance of the Pilot, the Instructor, the Line Check Airman or the Standards Captain.</P>
<B><P>F-5- </B>Provisions must be incorporated assuring that aircraft or simulator data used to enhance training is incorporated in the de-identified FOQA trend data.</P>
<B><P>G. </B>The pilot representatives involved in the Flight Operations Quality Assurance</P>
<P>(FOQA) Program shall be displaced from all or a portion of their scheduled trips in a cost effective manner while functioning in this capacity.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 125 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-13</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have signed this Agreement this 24th day of September, 1997.</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>WITNESS: </P>
<P>FOR UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
</FONT><U><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>/s/ E.L. Soliday</P>
</U></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>E. L. Soliday, Vice President</P>
<P>Corporate Safety &amp; Security</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>WITNESS: </P>
<P>FOR THE AIR LINE PILOTS IN THE SERVICE OF UNITED AIR LINES, INC.</P>
</FONT><U><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>/s/ J. R. Babbitt</P>
</U></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>J. Randolph Babbitt, President</P>
<P>Air Line Pilots Association, International</P>
<P>FOR THE UNITED AIRLINES MASTER EXECUTIVE COUNCIL</P>
</FONT><U><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>Michael H. Glawe, Chairman UAL-MEC</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Ratified by the UAL -MEC 10/17/97.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Revised as of this 26th day of October, 2000.</P>
<U><P>/s/ William P. Hobgood</P>
</U><P>William P. Hobgood</P>
<P>Senior Vice President</P>
<P>People</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<U><P>/s/ F.C. Dubinsky</P>
</U><P>Captain F.C. Dubinsky</P>
<P>Chairman</P>
<P>UAL/ALPA Master Executive Council</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</FONT><B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Letter 9-1 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 126</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-1</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>DENTK Contract Training</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>January 6, 1998</P>
<P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Mike:</P>
<P>The purpose of this letter is to inform you of how the Company will address some</P>
<P>specific issues relative to how contract training is conducted and to the use of revenue sharing simulators.</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Contract Training</P>
<P>There are seven key areas that need to be properly managed: instruction, programs, simulator maintenance, facilities, scheduling, customer service and sales an marketing. The responsibility of each of these areas falls on either Flight Operations, UAL
Services (Flight Training Services), or both as set forth below:</P>
<U><P>Instruction</U> is the responsibility of Flight Operations "Wet" contract training for aircraft types United operates will be accomplished by Pilot Instructors on the UAL Pilot Seniority List in accordance with the Pilot Instructor Letter of
Agreement (89-2) and under virtually identical working conditions.</P>
<P>Necessary training will be provided to Pilot Instructors when required to conduct non-UAL syllabus programs.</P>
<U><P>Program development</U> is the responsibility of Flight Operations with coordination</P>
<P>support provided by FTS.</P>
<U><P>Simulator maintenance</U> is the responsibility of Flight Operations.</P>
<U><P>Facilities</U> provision and maintenance is the responsibility of Flight Operations.</P>
<U><P>Scheduling</U> is the responsibility of Flight Operations. FTS has responsibility for</P>
<P>scheduling of contract customers and to demonstrate "operational control" in</P>
<P>accordance with FAR Part 142 certification.</P>
<U><P>Customer Service</U> is the primary responsibility of FTS, but is also the responsibility of all United personnel who support contract training. FTS must coordinate each customer's entire training experience including: travel, hotel, scheduling,
contracts, payment, and changes to training, while accommodating cultural differences and any other special circumstances that may arise.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 127 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-1</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><U><P>Sales and marketing</U> is the responsibility of FTS. It is the responsibility of FTS to sell excess simulator and training capacity for United Airlines.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Revenue Share Simulators/Flight Training Devices</P>
<P>The Company is very supportive of the revenue share concept to the extent that it improves our flexibility to provide United pilot training and can generate revenues and profits for United Airlines when excess training capacity is available or sale by
United. Therefore, we would like to see its successful implementation by the following:</P>
<B><P>2-a- </B>Revenue Share simulators and flight training devices will be configured to meet existing UAL standards and maintained to those standards.</P>
<B><P>2-b- </B>The contract agreement with the revenue share partner states, among other things, that United Airlines can purchase the device at any time from the</P>
<P>commencement of the contract and has first right to purchase if the partner elects to remove the simulator</P>
<B><P>2-c- </B>United Airlines will purchase a revenue share device when it can be justified in accordance with corporate capital budgeting processes.</P>
<B><P>2-d- </B>In the event that United's pilot training needs exceed existing United owned or leased simulator capacity, United's pilot group will be given first priority when planning training times in the revenue share simulators.</P>
<P>Recognizing that this is a new concept, the Company will maintain a collaborative</P>
<P>relationship with ALPA in further developing these opportunities.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ Hart A. Langer</P>
</U><P>Hart Langer</P>
<P>Senior Vice President</P>
<P>Flight Operations</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<U><P>/s/ Stephan G. Regulinski</P>
</U><P>Stephan G. Regulinski</P>
<P>President</P>
<P>Services.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-2 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 128</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-2</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Standards Captain Job Share</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</I><B><P>U&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
NITED AIRLINES</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Mike:</P>
<P>The parties have agreed to the establishment of a voluntary Standards Captain Job Share program in which two pilots who hold a Captain bid on the same equipment, in the same domicile, will share the duties of a Standards Captain and a line pilot. ALPA
and the Company have jointly defined the procedures to administer this program as described in a letter to Captain Michael Glawe dated January 20, 1998. Additionally, the following provisions will apply to volunteers while participating in this program:</P>
<B><P>1. </B>During the months in which the pilot is functioning in his line assignment, he may volunteer to perform LCA duties if he so desires. There is no implied obligation. if the pilot does volunteer, he will be governed by the provisions of
Section 9.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>For the month in which he will be functioning as a line pilot, the Job Share Special Assignment (JS) pilot will participate in the preferencing and awarding process at his domicile in order to have a line and/or reserve assignment.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>ESOP contributions and the allocation of ESOP stock will be governed by the</P>
<P>appropriate ESOP documents.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>Month End Conflicts</P>
<B><P>4-a- </B>Pilots shall have the option to fly their inbound during the first days of special assignment at DENTK. The Company may request the pilot be removed from any portion of the inbound in order to be in position to begin his Standard Captain's
duties and he will be pay protected for the portion of the trip in the outbound month. All contractual rest provisions will be applied prior to the pilot beginning his Standard Captain's duties at DENTK.</P>
<B><P>4-b- </B>Pilots shall have the option to continue the DENTK duties of the JS pilot into the following month, the "line month". The Company may request the pilot be removed from any portion of his initial trip in the following month, if necessary,
in order to continue Standard Captain's duties and he will be pay protected for the portion of the trip in the following month. If, as a result of performing Standard Captain activities in the following month, "the line month", the pilot has less days off
than originally scheduled in his awarded line, these lost days will be restored to him in a following month in which he is assigned to DENTK or given to him as vacation credit days with his concurrence. All contractual rest provisions will be applied
prior to the pilot beginning his line and/or reserve assignment.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Page 129 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-2</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>5. </B>Vacation</P>
<B><P>5-a- </B>Each volunteer pilot functioning as a Job Share Standards Captain will</P>
<P>maintain any annual vacation awarded to him for the 1998/99 vacation year. If the awarded vacation split is scheduled for a month in which the pilot is on special assignment as a Job Share Standards Captain to the Fleet at DENTK, the appropriate
vacation day adjustment described in the Letter to Captain Michael Glawe dated January 20, 1998, will be applied. Remaining unawarded vacation may be taken by the Job Share Standards Captain either while functioning on the line or DENTK depending on where
he is assigned for the particular month. This monthly vacation will be awarded under Section 11-E of the Pilot Agreement or UAL Series 15 policy as appropriate. The above procedures will apply prospectively to any pilot who enters the Standards Captains
Job Share program after the awarding of the annual vacation.</P>
<B><P>5-b- </B>Beginning with the next full vacation year (1999/2000), volunteer pilots on special assignment functioning as Job Share Standards Captains, will have half of their accrued vacation allocated to be taken while flying their line assignment
and the remaining half adjusted, per the Letter to Captain Glawe dated January 20, 1998, to be taken while performing as a Job Share Standards Captain at DENTK. The appropriate previsions of Section 11 of the Pilot Agreement will apply for the bidding and
awarding of annual and monthly vacation while the pilot is flying his line assignment at the domicile and UAL. Series 15 policy will apply to the bidding and awarding of both annual and monthly vacation while the pilot is on special assignment as a
volunteer Standards Captain at DENTK.</P>
<P>If this properly represents our understanding, please sign and return (2) copies of this letter for our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ Charles H. Vanderheiden</P>
</U><P>Charles H. Vanderheiden</P>
<P>Director Labor Relations, Flight Employees</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>23rd day of January 1998.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-3 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 130</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-3</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Management Pilot Definition</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, II 60018</P>
<P>Re: Standards Captain Job Share Special Assignment Agreement</P>
<P>Dear Mike:</P>
<P>This letter will confirm our agreement that during any period when a pilot is in fact</P>
<P>functioning for United as a Standards Captain under the terms of Letter of Agreement 9-2, he is, insofar as pay, working conditions, performance of his actual job duties and the responsibilities relating thereto, a management employee. Accordingly,
ALPA shall have no representational rights or obligations to any such pilot with respect to any issue relating to that pilot's employment as a Standards Captain. ALPA will continue, of course, to represent any such pilot as to other matters governed by
the terms of the Agreement and for all purposes during those periods when the pilot is functioning as a line pilot.</P>
<P>If this properly represents our understanding, please sign and return (2) copies of this letter for our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<P>/s/ Hart A. Langer Captain</P>
<P>Hart A. Langer</P>
<P>Senior Vice President</P>
<P>Flight Operations</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>23rd day of January 1998.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 131 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-6</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-6</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Domicile Swap Enhancement</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018-7180</P>
<P>Dear Michael,</P>
<P>As it is not the intent of the Company or the Association to limit a pilot to one domicile trade in his probationary year, the parties agree that this letter shall amend and replace Letter of Agreement 91-22.</P>
<P>Effective February I, 1998, any pilot in his probationary year, while occupying the</P>
<P>assignment which he received upon initial employment as a pilot, shall be eligible to enter into voluntary domicile trades, as follows:</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Any pilot desiring to change domiciles under this provision must locate another</P>
<P>eligible pilot at the desired domicile with whom to trade. To be eligible to enter into a domicile trade, both pilots must hold assignments in the same status and equipment that they were initially trained for at DENTK as described above.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Both pilots involved must approve the trade. All pilots on the Pilot Eligibility</P>
<P>Seniority List whose seniority falls between these two pilots have thirty (30) days from posting of the notice to object to such trade. The Association will collect and maintain the necessary records of approvals.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>Upon written notification to the Company by the Association that a trade has been agreed upon, without objection as provided under 2 above, the mutual transfer will be made effective on the first day of the next month for which schedules
have not been posted for preferencing.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>Pilots who make domicile changes under this provision will not receive Company paid moves nor be covered by any of the other provisions of Section 10. Such pilots will also accomplish necessary travel on their own time and will not receive
Company paid time off for "travel days".</P>
<B><P>5. </B>Bidding restrictions ("freezes") already in place will be unaffected by a domicile</P>
<P>trade. A trade will not generate a new freeze nor add to an existing one.</P>
<B><P>6. </B>Any awarded vacation will be unaffected by a domicile trade.</P>
<B><P>7. </B>There will not be a limit on the number of domicile trades, as long as the pilots</P>
<P>involved meet all of the requirements of this Letter. If this accurately reflects our</P>
<P>understanding, please sign and return 2 copies for our files.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 132</P>
</B><P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ Charles H. Vanderheiden</P>
</U><P>Charles H. Vanderheiden</P>
<P>Director Labor Relations - Flight</P>
<P>Employees</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>2nd day of February 1998.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Captain Michael Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 403</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>9-8</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Simulator Scheduling Protocol</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED
AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;April 30, 1998</P>
<B><P>United Airlines DENTK Simulator Scheduling Protocol</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</B><P>The attached Scheduling Protocol document has been developed in a cooperative spirit by representatives of ALPA, Flight Operations, and UAL Services (Flight Training Services). The purpose of this document is to provide a protocol to all trainees
(United Airlines and Contract), instructors (United Airlines and Contract), management employees, and customers as to the use and prioritization of assets at the Flight Center.</P>
<P>It is the intent of all responsible parties to provide a quality training environment for all trainees who come to the Flight Center. To that end, the Scheduling Protocol document contains language which addresses the scheduling of simulators (and
other flight training devices), classrooms, and instructors. The document also addresses the use of Revenue Sharing simulators, sale of guarantee simulator times, and prioritization of assets during operational changes.</P>
<P>This document is intended to be a living document which will be reviewed and</P>
<P>modified by mutual agreement to reflect the needs of all trainees who come to the Flight Center. By signing this document each party gives their support to abide by and support the implementation of the scheduling protocols.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Michael H. Glawe</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>Chairman, UAL-MEC Air</P>
<P>Line Pilots Association</P>
</FONT><U><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>/s/ Hart A. Langer</P>
</U><P>Hart A. Langer</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>Sr. Vice-President Flight</P>
<P>Operations</P>
</FONT><U><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>/s/ Andy Studdert</P>
</U><P>Andrew R Studdert</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=2><P>Sr. Vice-President Fleet.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</FONT><B><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>Page 404 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-8</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DENTK SIMULATOR SCHEDULING PROTOCOL</P>
</B><P>Prologue: . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2</P>
<P>Chapter 1: Definitions . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2</P>
<P>Chapter 2: Sale of Guaranteed Simulator Time . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 4</P>
<P>Chapter 3: Revenue Sharing Simulator Access &amp; Scheduling . . . . . 4</P>
<P>Chapter 4: Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phase . . . . . . . . . 5</P>
<P>Chapter 5: Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 6</P>
<P>Chapter 6: General . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8</P>
<P>Chapter 7: Some examples . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 8</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;Prologue</P>
</B><P>The purpose of accurate planning/scheduling for Flight Center activities is to ensure adequate resources are available to accomplish UAL training on the scheduled day as planned. There are three timelines in scheduling training events: Long-range
Sale of Guaranteed Simulator Time, Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phase, and the Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase. This Protocol only applies to the current UAL Fleets.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter 1: Definitions</P>
<P>1. <U>C.B.A</B>.</U>: Collective Bargaining Agreement between United Airlines and the Air line Pilots Association.</P>
<B><P>2. <I><U>Daily Planning and Scheduling Phas</I>e</B></U>: from the 16th of the month prior to the Operational Month throughout the Operational Day.</P>
<B><P>3. <I><U>Dry Contract Trainin</I>g</B></U>: Contract Training that is sold only with a Simulator (or</P>
<P>FBS).</P>
<B><P>4. <I><U>FB</I>S</U>:</B> A Fixed Base Simulator which has no motion or visual capability. Also</P>
<P>referred to as FMAST or CPT.</P>
<B><P>5. <I><U>Fleet Captai</I>n</B></U>: Fleet Captain or his designee.</P>
<B><P>6. <I><U>FT</I>S</B></U>: Flight Training Services, a business unit of UAL Services which is charged with the sale and marketing of Wet and Dry Contract Training.</P>
<B><P>7. <I><U>Guaranteed Simulator Tim</I>e</B></U>: Simulator (or FBS) time that is sold to an FTS</P>
<P>customer (Wet or Dry) that cannot be canceled or changed without incurring a</P>
<P>financial cancellation penalty for United Airlines. This guarantee implies day of week or time of day.</P>
<B><P>8. <I><U>Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phas</I>e</B></U>: any time period prior to the 16th of the month prior to the Operational Month.</P>
<B><P>9. <I><U>MRI Tea</I>m</B></U>: Mutual Resolutions of Issues Team consisting of FTS, UAL Flight</P>
<P>Operations, and ALPA participants.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 405</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>10. <I><U>Nonguaranteed Simulator Tim</I>e</B></U>: Simulator (or FBS) time that is sold to an FTS customer (Wet or Dry) that can be canceled or moved any time (except as listed in this Protocol).</P>
<B><P>11. <I><U>Off Campus Trainin</I>g</B></U>: Simulator Training that is performed at a non-United</P>
<P>Airlines Facility.</P>
<B><P>12. <I><U>Operational Mont</I>h</B></U>: (as defined in Section 2-O of C.B.A.) The Scheduling Month (for example, the Operational Month of February is defined as the 31st January through 1 March).</P>
<B><P>13. <I><U>Operational Da</I>y</B></U>: For Simulator periods starting at 06:00 on the date till 05:59 Local Time the next day (for example, the Operational Day of the 2nd of March runs from 06:00 the 2nd until 05:59 of the 3rd).</P>
<B><P>14. <I><U>Overflow Trainin</I>g</B></U>: All planned training that exceeds available UAL simulator time (approximately 80% of the Planned Capacity) in an Operational Month, in a given Fleet.</P>
<B><P>15. <I><U>Planned Capacit</I>y</B></U>: Total Simulator Time available for use from 06:00 to 02:00.</P>
<B><P>16. <I><U>Reserve Buffe</I>r</B></U>: a block of Simulator (or FSS) time in a given Fleet that is</P>
<P>allocated in the Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phase to be used during</P>
<P>unplanned events.</P>
<B><P>17. <I><U>Reserve "M" Buffe</I>r</B></U>: Maintenance time from 02:00 to 06:00 that can potentially be used, with Simulator Services, Fleet Captain, Instructor, and FTS crew concurrence, as a Reserve Buffer for FTS activities.</P>
<B><P>18. <I><U>Revenue Sharing Simulato</I>r</B></U>: a Simulator owned by a Simulator Manufacturer and used at DENTK for increased flexibility, Overflow Training, and additional revenue.</P>
<B><P>19. <I><U>Simulator Service</I>s</B></U>: A Flight Operations division which performs maintenance for Simulators and FBS's.</P>
<B><P>20. <I><U>Sold Simulator Tim</I>e</B></U>: Simulator (or FBS) time in a given Fleet that has been sold to a FTS customer (Wet or Dry) for the purpose of a planned (new) activity, as compared to recouping lost Simulator time due to maintenance
problems, UAL higher priority requirements, and/or FTS crew additional training requirements.</P>
<B><P>21. <I><U>Surplus Capacit</I>y</B></U>: All Simulator time leftover for sale, after UAL Flight</P>
<P>Operations, Maintenance needs, and Reserve Buffers are planned for in the Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phase.</P>
<B><P>22. <I><U>UAL Simulato</I>r</B></U>: a Simulator owned or leased by UAL Flight Operations.</P>
<B><P>23. <I><U>Wet Contract Trainin</I>g</B></U>: Contract Training that is sold with a Simulator (or FBS) and a United Airlines instructor.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 406 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-8</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter 2: Sale of Guaranteed Simulator Time</P>
<P>1. </B>FTS may guarantee Surplus Capacity simulator time on a day specific basis, with exceptions only to be approved by the Fleet Captain, with the following restrictions:</P>
<B><P>1-a- </B>Based upon the latest Training Plan supplied by WHQ, historical data,</P>
<P>DENTK Scheduling, Fleet planning, arid Simulator Services, the Fleet Captain will determine the total amount of Surplus Capacity in his Fleet. The Fleet Captain, with input from FTS, will determine the amount of simulator time, in that Fleet, that can
be sold as Guaranteed Simulator Time.</P>
<B><P>1-b- </B>In a Fleet with a Revenue Sharing Simulator, the Fleet Captain and FTS, in a collaborative fashion, will determine the amount of simulator time that can be sold as Guaranteed Simulator Time.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Guaranteed Simulator time can be sold no further out than 90 days from the</P>
<P>Operational Day, with the exception to be approved by the Fleet Captain and the MRI Team.</P>
<B><P>3. AFTER </B>UAL scheduling needs in a particular Fleet are met, FTS can schedule</P>
<P>Guaranteed Simulator Time for a specific time of day after approximately the 1st of the month prior to the Operational Month. For example: the 1st of March for the Operational Month of April.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>In <B>NO </B>case will the sale of Guaranteed Simulator Time generate the need for UAL pilots in training to go Off Campus for flight training.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>In <B>NO </B>case will the sale of Guaranteed Simulator Time impact the ability for</P>
<P>Simulator Services to be able to perform routine and non- routing Simulator</P>
<P>Maintenance.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter 3: Revenue Sharing Simulator Access &amp; Scheduling</P>
<P>1. <I><U>TRIGGER </I>1</B></U>: The Revenue Sharing Simulators will be utilized when Overflow</P>
<P>Training, in a given Fleet, is projected during an Operational Month. UAI Flight</P>
<P>Operations will have first priority in scheduling this Overflow Training into the</P>
<P>Revenue Sharing Simulator.</P>
<B><P>2. <I><U>TRIGGER </I>2</B></U>: During the Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phase, if UAL Flight Operations needs are projected to use 25% or more of the 24:00 to 02:00 time slot in an Operational Month in a given Fleet, those incremental UAL
crews will then be scheduled into the Revenue Sharing Simulator. Every effort will he made to sell enough simulator time to make this a cost neutral transaction.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>During the Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase, if a Scheduling Disruption occurs, the Revenue Sharing Simulators should be used to accommodate crews according to Chapter 5: Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase of this Protocol</P>
<B><P>4. </B>In NO case will the sale of Revenue Sharing Simulator Time by FTS, generate the need for UAL pilots in training to go Off Campus for flight training.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 407</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>5. </B>United Airlines will purchase all Simulator Time scheduled in a Revenue Sharing Simulator at the agreed upon rate.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter 4: Long-range Planning and Scheduling Phase</P>
</B><P>The purpose of accurate planning is to ensure that United Airlines personnel are given first choice to meet their training and maintenance requirements in accordance with the C.B.A. The Long-range Planning Phase has many key events which require
coordination between the Fleets, Simulator Services, Scheduling, and Flight Training Services.</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Priority of scheduling resources (Simulators, flight training devices, classrooms, Learning Center, etc.) for training and Simulator maintenance will be given to all UAL Flight Operations requirements. Classes will be built for all known UAL
training requirements including:</P>
<B><P>1-a- </B>Proficiency Checks</P>
<B><P>1-b- </B>Initial, Transition, Upgrade, Requalification courses, and other Specialty</P>
<P>courses</P>
<B><P>1-c- </B>Instructor/Evaluator training courses</P>
<B><P>1-d- </B>Fleet development projects (as determined by the Fleet Captain)</P>
<B><P>2. </B>Simulator maintenance will be scheduled in a manner which best accommodates the needs of the Fleet and Simulator Services, as determined by the Fleet Captain. This need can also include FTS. For example: in order to sell a particular FTS
Contract, a simulator might require a modification or update.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>Adequate Reserve Buffers (for UAL Flight Operations, Wet and Dry Contract</P>
<P>Training) will be established to provide reasonable unplanned capacity to</P>
<P>accommodate schedule disruptions which occur after the Long-range Planning Phase, including the following parameters:</P>
<B><P>3-a- </B>Unplanned Simulator Maintenance</P>
<B><P>3-b- </B>Additional training requirements</P>
<B><P>3-c- </B>Rechecks</P>
<B><P>3-d- </B>Any other subjective buffers deemed prudent (i.e. weather, holiday etc.) as determined by the Fleet Captain.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>The scheduling for UAL pilots in training for the most desirable time will be as</P>
<P>provided in the C.B.A. Section 9-G-9.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>After completion of the Long-range Planning process (UAL Flight Operations</P>
<P>training and Maintenance requirements and all Reserve Buffers have been planned) all remaining Surplus Capacity can be released for sale by FTS.</P>
<B><P>6. NO </B>Reserve Buffer time will be sold by FTS without Fleet Captain approval, and then only on a "non-guaranteed" basis.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 408 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-8</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>7. NO </B>Reserve "M" Buffer will be sold by FTS without Fleet Captain and Simulator Services approval, and then only on a "non-guaranteed" basis.</P>
<B><P>8. </B>Surplus Capacity that has been released to FTS, but has not been sold, may be reclaimed by Flight Operations, if needed, as determined by the Fleet Captain</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter 5: Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase</P>
</B><P>The purpose of Daily Planning and Scheduling is to administer the Long-range Plan and make adjustments as necessary to minimize disruptions and establish a priority system when disruptions occur.</P>
<B><P>1. </B>Reserve Buffers will be allocated on a priority basis, as needed. The scheduling for UAL pilots in training for the most desirable time will be as provided in the C.B.A. Section 9-G-9.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>NO Reserve Buffer time will be sold by FTS without Fleet Captain approval, and then only on a "non-guaranteed" basis.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>NO Reserve "M" Buffer will be sold by FTS without Fleet Captain and Simulator Services approval, and then only on a "nonguaranteed" basis.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>Once ANY actual Simulator/FBS training session has started (not including the</P>
<P>briefing), the training session shall not be canceled and/or delayed substantially</P>
<P>without permission from the Instructor involved unless the Fleet Captain, with</P>
<P>appropriate coordination, authorizes the interruption (the session will still have to end at its regular scheduled time period, as per priority 7 below).</P>
<B><P>5. </B>In the event that a UAL crew's training period is disrupted and in the judgment of the Instructor involved that training is negatively impacted, then the training event will be rescheduled in its entirety and the period that was disrupted
will not count toward the completion of that course.</P>
<B><P>6. </B>If the Reserve "M" Buffer is needed in the Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase, and Simulator Services approval is given, the following priority will be adhered to:</P>
<B><P>6-a- </B>All priority will be given to moving Dry Contract Training in that time slot.</P>
<B><P>6-b- </B>If no Dry Contract Training can be moved into the Reserve "M" Buffer, and extra simulator time is still needed, FTS will attempt to delay the Wet Contract Class to the next possible slot, probably the next day.</P>
<B><P>6-c- </B>If no other alternatives are viable, Wet Contract Training can be moved into the Reserve "M" Buffer, with Instructor and Crew concurrence. The rest and duty requirements for the Pl's associated with these assignments are addressed
separately by the Company and ALPA in the Pl Guidelines.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 409</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>7. </B>For the Operational Day during a disruption with no sufficient Reserve Buffers</P>
<P>available, the following priority list indicates the highest to the lowest priority. Events A, B, C, and D are expected to complete their full scheduled event, all other events should reduce their Simulator time to get back on schedule. When a
training event needs to be canceled or moved, the priority list will be applied in reverse order:</P>
<B><P>7-a- </B>Any UAL Operational Currency event (i.e. Landing Currency)</P>
<B><P>7-b- </B>UAL PC's &amp; CQP Day 1, 2, &amp; 3 (Annual Training Events)</P>
<B><P>7-c- </B>UAL and FTS (Wet or Dry) Transition course check rides, LOE's, and</P>
<P>Validations</P>
<B><P>7-d- </B>UAL Transition training periods within two periods of a Check or LOE, and within one period of a Validation event</P>
<B><P>7-e- </B>Any UAL Scheduled Training</P>
<B><P>7-f- </B>Fleet Projects, as determined by the Fleet Captain</P>
<B><P>7-g- </B>Any Guaranteed FTS Scheduled Events</P>
<B><P>7-h- </B>Any nonguaranteed FTS previously Scheduled Events</P>
<B><P>7-i- </B>FTS Events (i.e. sold Reserve Buffer time)</P>
<B><P>7-j- </B>All other events</P>
<B><P>8. </B>If a UAL and FTS event fall within the same priority category, UAL events will take priority over FTS events.</P>
<B><P>9. </B>The Daily Scheduler must manage the schedule disruptions so as to minimize the effects of that disruption on as few crews as is possible. In the event of a mechanical disruption and/or a Simulator period running over its normally scheduled
time, the next scheduled period will normally absorb the overage, as determined by the priority list above, unless the Daily Scheduler, in conjunction with the Fleet Captain, and if possible, the involved Instructors, determines an alternative plan would
be more advantageous.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter
6: General</P>
<P>1. </B>Because of the unique nature of the Simulator Scheduling Protocol, the MRI Team will on a monthly basis review, monitor, report, and if necessary, make</P>
<P>recommendations and changes in the following areas:</P>
<B><P>1-a- </B>The sale of Guaranteed Simulator Time.</P>
<B><P>1-b- </B>The use of the Revenue Sharing Simulators. A periodic study will be</P>
<P>performed on the entire Revenue Sharing Simulator concept, including the</P>
<P>potential purchase.</P>
<B><P>1-c- </B>The concept of Reserve Buffers, utilizing such measures as:</P>
<B><P>1-c-1- </B>All Planned versus Actually used Reserve Buffer time slots in the</P>
<P>previous month.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 410 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-8</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>1-c-2- </B>What kind of activity was scheduled and who used the Reserve Buffers</P>
<B><P>1-d- </B>A Simulator (or FBS) usage report of the Reserve "M" Buffers. A study will be performed anytime the usage of the Reserve "M" Buffer exceeds 5% per month in a given fleet. The report of this study will include the following:</P>
<B><P>1-d-1- </B>Reasons for the high Reserve "M" Buffer usage</P>
<B><P>1-d-2- </B>If this is just an anomaly or whether this is an upward trend</P>
<B><P>1-d-3- </B>Necessary Reserve Buffer adjustments</P>
<B><P>1-d-4- </B>Additional simulator capacity justification</P>
<B><P>1-d-5- </B>Other relevant facts, as determined by the MRI Team</P>
<B><P>1-e- </B>Long-range and Daily Planning and Scheduling Phase.</P>
<B><P>1-f- </B>Other relevant facts, as determined by the MRI Team.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>In either case, approximately 6 months after the start of the full implementation of the Simulator Scheduling Protocol, all appropriate parties involved will perform a thorough review and publish a report.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>In case of a dispute over access to any UAL Simulator or Device, the Fleet Captain will make the final determination.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>In case of dispute over access to a Revenue Sharing Simulator, the Fleet Captain and FTS, in a collaborative fashion, will make the final determination. In the event no satisfactory resolution can be reached in a timely fashion, the Fleet
Captain will make the final determination.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>In keeping with the spirit of cooperation between the Company and ALPA, all</P>
<P>current and future matters regarding the DENTK Simulator Scheduling Protocol topic will be resolved in a collaborative fashion.</P>
<B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Chapter 7: Some examples</P>
<P>Example (A):</P>
<P>The Long-range Schedule reflects the following in Simulator 1:</P>
<P>- </B>FTS Transition Check ride from 06:00 to 10:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 3 from 10:00 to 14:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 2 from 14:00 to 18:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 3 from 18:00 to 22:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS "Dry" Transition Period 8 from 22:00 to 02:00</P>
<P>The Simulator is running 1 hour late due to <U>mechanical problems</U>. The Schedule will now reflect the minimizing of scheduling disruptions, <U>with no Reserve Buffers</P>
<P>available</U>, on the Operational Day:</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS Transition Check ride from 07:00 to 11:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 3 from 11:00 to 15:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 2 from 15:00 to 19:00.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 9-8 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 411</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 3 from 19:00 to 22:00 (this crew "eats" it) **</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS "Dry" Transition Period 8 from 22:00 to 02:00</P>
<P>* *unless the Daily Scheduler determines it would be more feasible for the UAL crew to continue</P>
<B><P>Example (B):</P>
<P>The Long-range Schedule reflects the following in Simulator 1:</P>
<P>- </B>FTS Transition Check ride from 06:00 to 10:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 3 from 10:00 to 14:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 6 from 14:00 to 18:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>Reserve Buffer from 18:00 to 20:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 3 from 20:00 to 00:00</P>
<P>The Simulator is running 1 hour late due to <U>mechanical problems</U>. The Schedule will now reflect the minimizing of scheduling disruptions, <U>with Reserve Buffers available</U>, on the Operational Day:</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS Transition Check ride from 07:00 to 11:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 3 from 11:00 to 15:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 6 from 15:00 to 19:00 (this crew does not have to eat</P>
<P>it)</P>
<B><P>- </B>Reserve Buffer from 19:00 to 20:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 3 from 20:00 to 00:00</P>
<B><P>Example (C):</P>
<P>The Long-range Schedule reflects the following in Simulator 1:</P>
<P>- </B>FTS Guaranteed Dry Transition Period 6 from 06:00 to 10:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 3 from 10:00 to 14:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 2 from 14:00 to 18:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 7 from 18:00 to 22:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS Nonguaranteed Transition Period 3 from 22:00 to 02:00</P>
<P>UAL needs one <U>additional simulator period</U> for a Check ride, and <U>no Reserve Buffer</U> is</P>
<P>available:</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS Guaranteed Dry Transition Period 6 from 06:00 to 07:00 **</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Check ride from 07:00 to 10:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 3 from 10:00 to 14:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 2 from 14:00 to 18:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 7 from 18:00 to 22:00.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 412 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 9-8</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>- </B>FTS Nonguaranteed Transition Period 3 from 22:00 to 02:00</P>
<P>** If Reserve "M" Buffer available, this FTS simulator period could possibly move up earlier</P>
<B><P>Example (D):</P>
<P>The Long-range Schedule reflects the following in Simulator 1:</P>
<P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 3 from 06:00 to 10:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 8 from 10:00 to 14:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS Transition Period 8 from14:00 to 18:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 1 from 18:00 to 20:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>FTS Transition Period 3 from 20:00 to 00:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>Maintenance upgrade from 00:00 to 06:00</P>
<P>UAL Transition Period 8 experiences a <U>mechanical problem and is now 2 hours late</U>. The Schedule will now reflect the minimizing of scheduling disruptions on the Operational Day:</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 3 from 06:00 to 10:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL Transition Period 8 from 10:00 to 16:00 FTS</P>
<B><P>- </B>Transition Period 8 from 16:00 to 18:00 (this crew "eats" it)</P>
<B><P>- </B>UAL PC Day 1 from 18:00 to 20:00 FTS</P>
<B><P>- </B>Transition Period 3 from 20:00 to 00:00</P>
<B><P>- </B>Maintenance upgrade from 00:00 to 06.00.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 98-13 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 413</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>98-13</P>
</FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>777 Crew Rest</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</I><B><P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Mike:</P>
<P>The Company has indicated a desire to introduce the B777 model aircraft into the Pacific operation. This strategy will likely prevent market fragmentation and sustain the efficient operation of current routes that no longer support the use of the
B747- 400. Additionally, the introduction of the B777-B model aircraft on such routes will provide long-term growth opportunities including increased B747-400 operations into the Pacific. Therefore, to facilitate the Company's operation of Pacific ETOPS
flight segments with B777 model aircraft, the parties have agreed to install an ALPA approved rest facility as follows:</P>
<B><P>1. </B>The Company will equip all current and future B777-B model aircraft with a crew bunk facility similar to the B747-400 aircraft. Until the crew bunk facility is installed on B777-B model aircraft, the Genesis seat will serve as the pilot crew
rest facility. The Company will retrofit all current B777-B model aircraft with a crew bunk according to the agreed upon schedule, provided all of the variables pertaining to the retrofit occur as planned.</P>
<B><P>2. </B>The Company will retrofit all three class B777-B and B777-A model aircraft with a Genesis seat. The Company will complete the installation of Genesis seats on all B777-B and B777-A model aircraft according to the agreed upon schedules,
provided all of the variables pertaining to this retrofit occur as planned. The Company, however, is not obligated to equip B777 model aircraft dedicated to the domestic operation with crew bunks or Genesis seats and these aircraft will not be scheduled
nor substituted into the international operation.</P>
<B><P>3. </B>A joint committee comprised of Company and ALPA representatives will monitor the development and installation of the crew bunk facility and the Genesis seat to ensure compliance with this agreement.</P>
<B><P>4. </B>Prior to the installation of the crew bunks on the B777-B model aircraft, the</P>
<P>Company may only schedule Pacific ETOPS flight segments with aircraft equipped with the Genesis seat. The Company may, however, substitute a B777 model aircraft equipped without Genesis seats to avoid a cancellation. This substitution provision will
remain in effect until March 1, 2000, or until 12 B777 model aircraft are equipped with the Genesis seat, whichever occurs first. Additionally, the Company will provide the Association with documentation indicating the flight segments on which any.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Page 414 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 98-13</P>
</B><P>substitution was necessary and the reasons for the substitution. Completion of the installation of crew bunks and Genesis seats as set forth above resolves the crew rest issue on the B777 model aircraft utilized in the international operation and,
thereafter, the Company may continue to operate such aircraft in accordance with the terms of the Agreement.</P>
<B><P>5. </B>The Company will not operate augmented B767 flying in the Pacific until such</P>
<P>aircraft are fitted with an ALPA approved crew rest facility.</P>
<P>If this accurately reflects our understanding, please sign and return 2 copies for our files.</P>
<P>Sincerely,</P>
<U><P>/s/ William P. Hobgood</P>
</U><P>William P. Hobgood</P>
<P>Sr. Vice President- People</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<P>Accepted and agreed to this</P>
<P>18th day of December, 1998.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe</P>
</U><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association.</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
<B><P>Letter 98-14 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 415</P>
</FONT><I><FONT FACE="Arial" SIZE=1><P>Letter </B>98-14</P>
</I></FONT><FONT FACE="Arial"><P>&nbsp;</P>
<I><P>HNL Domicile</P>
<P>&nbsp;</P>
</I><B><P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P ALIGN="CENTER">LETTER OF AGREEMENT</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">Between</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIRLINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">And</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">in the service of</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">UNITED AIRLINES, INC.</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">as represented by</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">THE AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION,</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">INTERNATIONAL</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">&nbsp;</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">&nbsp;</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;THIS LETTER OF AGREEMENT is made and entered into in accordance with the provisions of Title II of the Railway Labor Act by and between UNITED AIRLINES, INC. (hereinafter referred to as "United" or the "Company"), and the
AIR LINE PILOTS in the service of UNITED AIRLINES, INC. as represented by the AIR LINE PILOTS ASSOCIATION, INTERNATIONAL (hereinafter referred to as "ALPA" or the "Association").</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">W I T N E S S E T H:</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER">It is hereby mutually agreed:</P>
<B><P>1. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B>The current Honolulu domicile established during the term of the 1991 Agreement will be limited to the B-747 except that short range equipment such as the B-737 and/or B-727 may also be introduced for inter-island service
only. Such inter-island equipment domicile may be established as either a permanent or TDY domicile. The Company will consult with the Association prior to establishing such inter-island Honolulu domicile. Additionally, the Company agrees to use Letter of
Agreement 97-4 (Allocation of Flying Protocol) prior to the introduction of any other equipment in the Honolulu domicile.</P>
<B><P>2. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B>As long as the B-747 flying supporting the Honolulu domicile is sufficient to</P>
<P>maintain a minimum line level, the domicile will remain open. As the system-wide B-747 flying is reduced due to the phasing out of the equipment, the reduction will be accomplished under the provisions of Section 8 of the Agreement. The Company and
the SSC shall monitor the B-747 flying on a monthly basis to assure compliance with this provision.</P>
<B><P>Page 416 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 98-14</P>
<P>3. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B>In construction of DSL pairings for the Honolulu B-747 equipment domicile, the Company will observe the scheduling philosophies required by Letter 91-7</P>
<P>(Scheduling Practices Letter). All Section 20 scheduling dispute resolution procedures will be available to address any problems associated with these parings, up to and including a review by the Senior Vice-President, Flight Operations.</P>
<B><P>4. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B>A paid move from the Hawaiian Islands to any point in the contiguous 48 states will be available to any pilot who (1) retires (including early or medical retirement) while based in Honolulu and (2) who has an established
residence in Hawaii. Notwithstanding the provisions of Section 10-C-3 of the Agreement, this move entitlement shall apply only to a move from the Hawaiian Islands to the Mainland.</P>
<B><P>5. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B>Bid but unfilled vacancies in Honolulu shall not be subject to involuntary</P>
<P>assignment under the provisions of Section 8-F of the Agreement, except the</P>
<P>Honolulu assignments may be given as initial assignments to newly hired pilots. In the event the Company is unable to fill vacancies at Honolulu, required manpower may be filled through the use of temporary duty under the provisions of Section 8-L of
the Agreement. For this purpose and notwithstanding the provisions of Section 8-L-3-b, a pilot may be involuntarily assigned up to 60 days of TDY per year, in addition to any voluntary TDY which he also may have performed. Further, notwithstanding the
provisions of Section 8-L-3-c, the normal minimum TDY assignment on Honolulu will be for a full schedule month.</P>
<B><P>6. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B>This Letter of Agreement shall become effective upon signing and run concurrently with Section 22 of the 1994 Pilot Agreement. The parties have signed this Letter of Agreement this 18th day of December, 1998.</P>
<P>FOR THE AIR LINE PILOTS</P>
<P>IN THE SERVICE OF</P>
<P>UNITED AIRLINES, INC. &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FOR UNITED AIRLINES, INC.</P>
<U><P>/s/ Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</U>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<U>/s/ William P. Hobgood</P>
</U><P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Senior Vice President</P>
<P>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;People Division</P>
<B><P>Letter 99-6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 417</P>
</B><I><P>B747-400 Currency</P>
</I><B><P>UNITED AIRLINES</P>
</B><P>Captain Michael H. Glawe, Chairman</P>
<P>UAL-MEC Air Line Pilots Association</P>
<P>6400 Shafer Court, Suite 700</P>
<P>Rosemont, IL 60018</P>
<P>Dear Captain Glawe:</P>
<P>The Association and the Company have jointly agreed to review the staffing and the currency requirements for augmented flying. This review has been separated into two distinct parts. One discusses temporary modifications to address currency
requirements. The other studies various methods of staffing augmented flights. The following procedures will apply until the staffing study is completed:</P>
<P>The B747-400 crews will, in addition to the PC/CQP, be scheduled for a PT as follows:</P>
<P>The PT will be scheduled in the same manner as a PC/CQP, using a base six (6)</P>
<P>months from the PC/CQP base month. The PT will comply with the PC/CQP scheduling rules of the Agreement. Travel to and from a PT will be the same as the PC/CQP.</P>
<P>In addition to the present landing currency requirements, all B747-400 first officers will be required to accomplish one (1) landing and take off in the aircraft within 180 consecutive days.</P>
<P>A new training opportunity will be implemented, an Operating Experience Refresher ("OER"). The OER will consist of at least two (2) segments in the aircraft. A minimum of one (1) segment will be flown with the pilot receiving the OER as the pilot
flying ("PF"). A check airman will conduct the OER. The check airman may extend the OER beyond the minimum two (2) legs if</P>
<P>necessary. The Company may assign an OER to a pilot during his last 30 calendar days of availability prior to the expiration of the 180-day landing/takeoff currency limit. During any time other than this last 30 calendar day period, the Company may
assign an OER only with pilot concurrence.</P>
<B><P>Page 418 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Letter 99-6</P>
</B><P>Lineholders who are subject to an OER as described in the above paragraph may be assigned up to the actual domestic limits of FAR 121.471. With pilot concurrence, The OER may be scheduled on days off in conjunction with</P>
<P>vacation. If the pilot refuses an OER on his vacation days off, any flying lost due to not qualified status ("NQ") will be pay protected to the 78-hour guarantee.</P>
<P>A first officer requiring an OER may be assigned an open flying ID or displace a</P>
<P>first officer in a flying ID.</P>
<P>Letter 91-28 will apply to OER's for reserve pilots in the same manner as IOE's.</P>
<P>Over-projection protection contained within Letter of Agreement 9-1 will apply to OER assignments. Consistent with 3-B-4-c-2, the pilot will be paid his line value or his line value after the OER modification, whichever is greater.</P>
<P>The following modifications will be implemented for the B747-400 schedules.</P>
<P>Commencing with the March 1999 schedule, lines of flying will be constructed to</P>
<P>include a combination of flying and non-flying ID's when possible. Specifically, one (1) flying ID will be traded for a non-flying ID provided it has the same schedule legs and pay value. First officer ID's with all domestic flying may be
redistributed to relief pilot lines' whenever possible.</P>
<P>First officers who have repeated two (2) training/checking events within twenty-four (24) months, or first officers with less than 75 hours in the aircraft, will not be</P>
<P>permitted to bid a line or be assigned an ID with a captain who has repeated two</P>
<P>(2) training/checking events within twenty-four (24) months or a captain with less</P>
<P>than 75 hours in the aircraft. If a first officer is paired with a captain who has not fulfilled the initial requirement of ten (10) landings, OPBCM may provide other flying that would maintain the first officer's landing currency. This modification
will require the first officer's concurrence. If the replacement flying is of a lesser value, the first officer will be pay protected for the greater. With his concurrence, a flight officer that could lapse landing currency may be removed from an ID and
assigned other flying to maintain his currency. If the replacement flying is of a lesser value, the flight officer will be pay protected for the greater.</P>
<B><P>Letter 99-6 &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Page 419</P>
</B><P>Pilots will be prohibited from trading out of a flying ID when they have exceeded</P>
